{{Infobox wildfire |title=2010 Russian wildfires |image=Russia TMO 2010216 lrg.jpg |caption=Smoke over western Russia on {{Nowrap|4 August}} 2010 |url= |location=Russia{{cite web|last=Henry|first=Patrick|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-08-05/russian-wildfires-death-toll-rises-to-50-drought-may-force-export-ban.html|title=Russian Wildfires' Death Toll Rises to 50; Drought May Force Export Ban|publisher=Bloomberg|date=3 August 2010 |accessdate=7 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100807095831/http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2010-08-05/russian-wildfires-death-toll-rises-to-50-drought-may-force-export-ban.html| archivedate= 7 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} |date= late July 2010 – early September 2010 |acres= |cause = |area={{convert|300000|ha|acre}}[http://hqweb.unep.org/yearbook/2011/ UNEP Year Book2011, An Overview of Our Changing Environment] {{webarchive|url=https://www.webcitation.org/6HtqIuKst?url=http://hqweb.unep.org/yearbook/2011/ |date=6 July 2013 }}, United Nations Environment Programme 2011 page 3 |landuse= villages, farmland, woodlands |buildings=2,000 |fatalities=54 in wildfires
55,736 in heat wave[http://cred.be/sites/default/files/PressConference2010.pdf Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters]}} [[File:Fire Cloud over Northern Russia.jpg|thumb|[[Pyrocumulonimbus cloud]] (circular cloud, left) caused by 1 August 2010 wildfires.]] The '''2010 Russian wildfires''' were several hundred [[wildfires]] that broke out across [[Russia]], primarily in [[European Russia|the west]] in summer 2010. They started burning in late July and lasted until early September 2010. The fires were associated with record-high temperatures, which were attributed to [[climate change]]{{Cite journal | last1 = Hansen | first1 = J. | authorlink1 = James Hansen| last2 = Sato | first2 = M. | last3 = Ruedy | first3 = R. | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1205276109 | title = PNAS Plus: Perception of climate change | journal = [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences]] | volume = 109 | issue = 37 | pages = E2415 | year = 2012 | pmid = | pmc = 3443154}}—the summer had been the hottest recorded in Russian history{{cite web|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/Russia-Wildfires-Rage-Amid-Record-Heat-99850004.html?refresh=1|title=Russia Wildfires Rage Amid Record Heat | News | English|publisher=.voanews.com|date=3 August 2010|accessdate=10 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100804205402/http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/Russia-Wildfires-Rage-Amid-Record-Heat-99850004.html?refresh=1| archivedate= 4 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}—and [[drought]]. Russian [[President of Russia|President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] declared a [[state of emergency]] in seven regions, and 28 other regions were under a state of emergency due to [[crop failures]] caused by the drought.{{cite news|last=Kramer|first=Andrew|title=A smoky curtain falls on Moscow|url=http://www.theage.com.au/world/a-smoky-curtain-falls-on-moscow-20100807-11pcw.html|accessdate=7 August 2010|newspaper=theage.com.au|date=8 August 2010|location=Melbourne}} The fires cost roughly $15 billion in damages. A combination of the smoke from the fires, producing heavy [[smog]] blanketing large urban regions and the record-breaking [[2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat wave#Russia|heat wave]] put stress on the Russian [[healthcare system]]. [[Munich Re]] estimated that in all, 56,000 people died from the effects of the smog and the heat wave.{{cite web|last=Writers|first=Staff|title=Natural disasters killed 295,000 in 2010: reinsurer|url=http://www.terradaily.com/reports/Natural_disasters_killed_295000_in_2010_reinsurer_999.html|work=Agence Presse-France|publisher=Disaster Management – Terra Daily|accessdate=3 January 2011}} The 2010 wildfires were the worst on record to that time. ==Prelude== {{Main article|2010 Northern Hemisphere summer heat wave}} [[File:NOAA Temperature anomalies June 2010.gif|thumb|Global temperature anomalies in June 2010, showing a concentrated region of temperatures about 4–5 °C+ above average in Western Russia.]] During 2010 Russia experienced dry, hot weather starting around late May and lasting until early June. Temperatures of {{Convert|35|°C}} first occurred after 12 June, which alone was an abnormality for the country (average mid-June temperatures seldom rise above {{Convert|30|°C}}). In late June, Russian regions such as the Eurasian [[Sakha Republic]], as well as areas of partial [[taiga]], had temperatures of {{Convert|38|-|40|°C|°F}}. The warm [[ridge (meteorology)|ridging]] pattern then slowly moved westward to the [[Ural Mountains]], and by July settled in European Russia. On 25 June a new temperature record was set in the Asian portion of Russia, at [[Belogorsk, Amur Oblast]], at {{Convert|42.3|C}}. The previous record in the Asian portion was {{Convert|41.7|C}} at [[Aksha, Russia|Aksha]] on 21 July 2004. A new record for the highest nationwide temperature in Russia was set on 11 July, at {{Convert|44|°C}}, in [[Yashkul]], [[Kalmykia]] (in the European portion), beating the previous record of {{Convert|43.8|°C}} set on 6 August 1940, in Kalmykia.{{cite web|last=Masters |first=Jeff |title=Russia records its hottest temperature in history; 97L develops near Puerto Rico |url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1546 |publisher=Weather Underground |accessdate=19 July 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100722041822/http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1546 |archivedate=22 July 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} Average temperatures in the region increased to over {{Convert|35|°C}}. The mean high for European Russia recorded on 26 July reached {{Convert|40|°C}} during the day. During July 2010, a large portion of European Russia was more than 7 °C (12.6 °F) warmer than normal.{{cite web|last=Masters |first=Jeff |title=Bermuda eyes a weak Colin; new extreme heat record for Belarus |url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1569#commenttop |publisher=Weather Underground |accessdate=7 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100820002618/http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/comment.html?entrynum=1569 |archivedate=20 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} According to the director of the Global Fire Monitoring Centre (GFMC) Johann Goldammer, the wildfires were caused by "negligent [human] behaviour", such as lighting barbecues and fireworks in a densely wooded area.{{Cite journal|title = Russia counts environmental cost of wildfires|url = http://www.nature.com/news/2010/100812/full/news.2010.404.html|journal = Nature News|date = 2010-08-12|doi = 10.1038/news.2010.404|language = en|first = Natasha|last = Gilbert}} Such human activity, coupled with the unusually high temperatures over the Russian territories, catalyzed this record disturbance. ==Timeline== ===29 July=== [[Peat|Peat fires]] causing significant loss of properties and an unverified number of human fatalities started in the [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]], the [[Voronezh Oblast]], [[Moscow Oblast]], [[Ryazan Oblast]] and across central and western Russia due to unseasonably hot weather.{{cite news|url=http://www.boston.com/bigpicture/2010/08/russian_wildfires.html|title=Russian wildfires – The Big Picture|work=Boston Globe |accessdate=7 August 2010|date=2 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100804162604/http://www.boston.com/bigpicture/2010/08/russian_wildfires.html| archivedate= 4 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===31 July=== [[File:Incendies en Russie,2010-07-31.svg|thumb|Regions with wildfire spreading on 31 July.]] [[File:Smoke in Voronezh.JPG|thumb|Smoke in Voronezh Oblast.]] The head of [[EMERCOM]], [[Sergey Shoygu]], reported on 31 July 2010 that the fire situation in the seventeen [[federal subjects of Russia|federal subjects]] of Russia, especially in [[Vladimir Oblast|Vladimir]] and [[Moscow Oblast]]s, may be complicated. He claimed that in [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast]] the velocity of fires was 100 meters per minute, and the fiery air flow tore trees from the root, like a hurricane.[http://lenta.ru/news/2010/08/01/infire/ area of forest fires in Russia decreased] A [[YouTube]] video was uploaded, showing a group of men escaping from a burning village in [[Vyksa]] district by driving their car over a burning road.[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vOI6OCHerUI Youtube video of car driving through fire] ===1 August=== On 1 August 2010, the area of the forest fires was {{convert|114000|ha|km2|abbr=on}}. The Central Regional Center MOE Russia website reported that in Moscow Oblast 130 foci of natural fires were detected, covering the area of 880 hectares. Of those, 67 fires covered an area of 178 hectares. ===2 August=== [[File:Moscow Smog 08-2010.jpg|thumb|Smoke of the wildfires over Moscow.]] According to "[[Interfax]]" referring to the head of the National Center for Crisis Management of [[EMERCOM]] Vladimir Stepanov, as of {{Nowrap|2 August}} 2010, Russia revealed approximately 7,000 fires in the area over {{convert|500000|ha|km2|abbr=on}}. Fire was also burning in 14 federal subjects of Russia, and on {{Nowrap|2 August}} 2010, officials reported the death of 34 people.[http://lenta.ru/news/2010/08/02/fires/ Area fires in Russia increased to {{Nowrap|500 thousand}} hectares] Moscow on Monday was covered in smoke, with reduced road visibility.[http://lenta.ru/news/2010/08/02/smoke "Moscow once again enveloped with smoke from fires"] On Monday, 2 August 2010, [[Vladimir Putin]] scheduled a meeting with the [[List of heads of federal subjects of Russia|Governors]] of [[Voronezh Oblast|Voronezh]], [[Novgorod Oblast|Novgorod]], [[Samara Oblast|Samara]], Moscow, [[Ryazan Oblast|Ryazan]], and [[Vladimir Oblast]]s, as well as the Head of the [[Mordovia|Republic of Mordovia]]. ===4 August=== By 4 August, the wildfires were still burning over {{convert|188525|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, with a death toll of at least 48. Some fires burned in areas near the nuclear research center in [[Sarov]]. However [[Rosatom]] head [[Sergey Kiriyenko]] dismissed apprehension of an atomic explosion.{{cite news|last=Media Group|first=Rambler|script-title=ru:"Росатом" призвал не бояться ядерного взрыва в Сарове|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2010/08/04/noapocalypse|accessdate=5 August 2010|newspaper=Lenta.ru|date=4 August 2010|agency=ООО "Лента.Ру" (1999–2012)|language=Russian}} President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] cut short his summer break to return to Moscow for an emergency meeting of the national security council to address the crisis.{{cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-10865316 |work=BBC News |title=Medvedev cuts holiday as Russian wildfires kill 48 |date=4 August 2010 |accessdate=6 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805042717/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-10865316 |archivedate=5 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} At an international meeting on 30 July, amid the ongoing heat wave and wildfires, Medvedev announced on television that "practically everything is burning. The weather is anomalously hot. What's happening with the planet's climate right now needs to be a wake-up call to all of us, meaning all heads of state, all heads of social organizations, in order to take a more energetic approach to countering the [[global warming|global changes to the climate]]."{{cite news|last=Shuster |first=Simon |title=Will Russia's Heat Wave End Its Global-Warming Doubts? |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2008081,00.html?hpt=T2 |accessdate=5 August 2010 |newspaper=TIME |date=2 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100806163358/http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0%2C8599%2C2008081%2C00.html?hpt=T2 |archivedate=6 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }}{{cite news | url=http://journalistsresource.org/studies/environment/climate-change/perception-climate-change/ | title=Perception of Climate Change: Examining Extreme Temperatures}} JournalistsResource.org, retrieved 21 August 2012.{{cite journal | last1 = Hansen | first1 = James | last2 = Sato | first2 = Makiko | last3 = Ruedy | first3 = Reto | year = 2012 | title = Perception of climate change | journal = [[Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America]] | doi = 10.1073/pnas.1205276109 | url = http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2012/07/30/1205276109.abstract| pmc = 3443154 }} Medvedev sacked some of his senior navy officers after one fire destroyed Russian navy equipment.{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6732JC20100804|title=Russia's Medvedev sacks navy officers for base fire|date=4 August 2010|agency=Reuters|accessdate=4 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100810065731/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE6732JC20100804| archivedate= 10 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|url=http://www.nation.co.ke/News/world/Russian%20leader%20sacks%20top%20officers%20over%20fire%20/-/1068/971126/-/15by9e8/-|title=Russian leader sacks top officers over fire|date=4 August 2010|work=[[Daily Nation]]|accessdate=4 August 2010}} The officers were accused of "incomplete professional responsibility" after several buildings were allowed to burn down and vehicles and equipment destroyed.{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/08/201084224236533275.html|title=Medvedev sacks officials over fires|date=5 August 2010|work=[[Aljazeera]]|accessdate=5 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100805034240/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/europe/2010/08/201084224236533275.html| archivedate= 5 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} He suggested anyone who had neglected their duties would be prosecuted.{{cite news|author1=Gorst, Isabel |author2=Weaver, Courtney|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2010/08/04/AR2010080405255.html?hpid=moreheadlines|title=Medvedev orders investigation into Russian wildfires|date=4 August 2010|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=4 August 2010}} On the same day it was reported that another fire was approaching a major secret nuclear research facility in the city of [[Sarov]]. Environmental groups, such as the [[World Wide Fund for Nature|WWF]], and "non-systemic" opposition politicians suggested firefighting has been slowed down by the Forest Code law passed by the [[Duma]] in 2006 at the order of Putin.{{Cite web|title = The New Forest Code of Russia (2006): WWF’s Comments|url = http://www.wwf.ru/about/what_we_do/forests/codecs/forestcode/eng|website = www.wwf.ru|access-date = 2016-02-02}} The legislation transferred responsibility for the country's vast woodlands to regional authorities, putting 70,000 forestry guards out of work.{{cite news|author=Bryanski, Gleb|url=https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE6723BL20100803|title=Opposition says Putin law cripples Russia fire-fighting|date=3 August 2010|work=[[Reuters|Reuters Africa]]|accessdate=3 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100806115558/https://af.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idAFTRE6723BL20100803| archivedate= 6 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===5 August=== According to the Emergencies Ministry, there were 843 reported outbreaks of fires, including 47 peat fires. There were 73 large fires. The fires threatened an animal sanctuary for over 1,800 animals, including dogs and retired [[circus]] animals. Almost 600 fires were still burning in the country, and around 2,000 homes had been destroyed. The President fired several high-ranking military officials after fires burned through a secret military base.{{cite news|last=UKPA|first=Google|title=Wildfires threaten animal sanctuary|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ukpress/article/ALeqM5gu1saKQUPFvbXWiVr7XE1Wqie6Gg|accessdate=5 August 2010|newspaper=The Press Association|date=5 August 2010}} [[Carbon monoxide]] pollution in Moscow was four times above normal. Firefighters fought to prevent the wildfires from reaching [[Bryansk]], an area bordering Ukraine contaminated with radioactive material, including [[cesium-137]] and [[strontium-90]], in the soils following the 1986 [[Chernobyl disaster]]. Emergencies Minister [[Sergey Shoygu]] warned that fires could release [[radionuclide]]s into the air. He said that a new zone of [[radioactive pollution]] could emerge. Two fires broke out in the region but were contained.{{cite news|last=Ferris-Rotman|first=Amie|title=Russia fires pose nuclear threat, death toll hits 50|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE6741EQ._CH_.2400|accessdate=8 August 2010|newspaper=Reuters|date=5 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100806093615/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE6741EQ._CH_.2400| archivedate= 6 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Europe|first=VoANews|title=Smog From Spreading Russia Fires Chokes Moscow|url=http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/europe/Smog-From-Spreading-Russia-Fires-Chokes-Moscow-100166434.html|accessdate=8 August 2010|newspaper=Voice of America|date=6 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100823110254/http://www1.voanews.com/english/news/europe/Smog-From-Spreading-Russia-Fires-Chokes-Moscow-100166434.html| archivedate= 23 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news|last=Dispatches|first=Moscow|title=Russia's wildfires threaten nuclear sites|url=http://www.tehrantimes.com/index_View.asp?code=224417|accessdate=8 August 2010|newspaper=Tehran Times|date=8 August 2010}} ===6 August=== [[File:Moscow, Yasenevo, August 6 2010.jpg|thumb|left|Smoke in Moscow on 6 August 2010]] [[File:Смог над Х 14авг2010 от лес.пожаров Журавлевка VizuIMG 3479.JPG|thumb|left|Smoke in Kharkov on 14 August]] According to the Emergencies Ministry, there were registered 831 fires, including 42 peat fires. 80 large fires were registered in an area of {{convert|150800|ha|km2|abbr=on}}.{{cite web|url=http://lenta.ru/news/2010/08/06/fires|title=В России возросло число крупных пожаров|publisher=Lenta.ru|date=6 August 2010|accessdate=7 August 2010}} Almost 162,000 people were reported to be fighting with the flames in the regions of [[Moscow Oblast|Moscow]], [[Voronezh Oblast|Voronezh]], [[Nizhny Novgorod Oblast|Nizhny Novgorod]], [[Ryazan Oblast|Ryazan]], [[Ivanovo Oblast|Ivanovo]], [[Vladimir Oblast|Vladimir]], [[Yaroslavl Oblast|Yaroslavl]], [[Tver Oblast|Tver]], [[Sverdlovsk Oblast|Yekaterinburg]], [[Republic of Mordovia]], and [[Mari El|Mari El Republic]].{{cite web|url=http://infox.ru/accident/incident/2010/08/06/Vpyervyyye_za_poslye.phtml|script-title=ru:Крупных пожаров стало больше, погибли уже 52 человека|date=6 August 2010|publisher=Infox|language=Russian|accessdate=7 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100808044250/http://infox.ru/accident/incident/2010/08/06/Vpyervyyye_za_poslye.phtml| archivedate= 8 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} According to the State environmental agency "Mosekomonitoring", in the morning in Moscow, the maximum concentration of carbon monoxide in the air exceeded the acceptable norm by 3.6 times, the content of suspended particles by 2.8 times, and specific hydrocarbons by 1.5 times. The Moscow airports of [[Domodedovo International Airport|Domodedovo]] and [[Vnukovo International Airport|Vnukovo]] were unable to land more than 40 planes and were only able to send about 20 planes due to the strong haze caused by the smoke. As of 10 a.m., visibility at Domodedovo was 350 m and 300 m at Vnukovo. According to the Federal Air Transportation Agency, the [[Sheremetyevo International Airport|Sheremetyevo airport]] works as usual because of visibility of about 800 m. An international [[Association football|football]] [[friendly match]] (Russia–Bulgaria) scheduled for 11 August was moved to [[Saint Petersburg]].{{cite web|url=http://www.rfs.ru/node/123579 |script-title=ru:Товарищеский матч национальных сборных России и Болгарии перенесен в Санкт-Петербург |date=6 August 2010 |publisher=[[Russian Fooball Union|RFU]] |language=Russian |accessdate=7 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101128085356/http://rfs.ru/node/123579 |archivedate=28 November 2010 |df= }} Two [[Russian Premier League]] football games were postponed because of the severe environmental situation.{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=15385184&PageNum=0 |title=Russian Premier League postpones two matches over smog in Moscow |date=6 August 2010 |publisher=ITAR-TASS |accessdate=7 August 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} According to the [[Moderate-Resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer|spectrometric data]] received from the NASA satellites [[Terra (satellite)|Terra]] and [[Aqua (satellite)|Aqua]], the smoke from the fires in some places rose to a height of about 12 kilometers and ended up in the [[stratosphere]], which usually only occurs during volcanic eruptions.{{cite web|url=http://www.rian.ru/hs_news/20100806/262373259.html|script-title=ru:Дым от пожаров в России добрался до стратосферы|publisher=RIA Novosti|language=Russian|date=26 July 2010|accessdate=7 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100817070513/http://www.rian.ru/hs_news/20100806/262373259.html| archivedate= 17 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Satellite imagery showed that a cloud of smoke {{convert|1850|mi|km|abbr=on}} wide covered Western Russia.{{cite news|last=Sinclair |first=Lulu |title=Death Rate Surges In Russian Heatwave |url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Russias-Heatwave-Continues-With-Mortality-Rate-Rising-By-More-Than-A-Third-In-July/Article/201008115678202?f=rss |accessdate=7 August 2010 |newspaper=Sky News Online HD |date=6 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100808041128/http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Russias-Heatwave-Continues-With-Mortality-Rate-Rising-By-More-Than-A-Third-In-July/Article/201008115678202?f=rss |archivedate=8 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ===7 August=== [[File:Smog Moscow August 2010.jpg|thumb|Moscow, Yasenevo, Aivazovskogo street. Left – 17 June 2010, 20:22. Right – 7 August 2010, 17:05.]] [[File:Smoke from forest fires Sheremetyevo 20100807 01.JPG|thumb|Smoke in Sheremetyevo 7 August 2010.]] [[File:Smoke Layer Border at 7-8 km.JPG|thumb|The upper border of the smoke layer (7–8 km) above the Moscow region.]] Emergency officials registered 853 outbreaks of fire by 7 August, including 32 [[peat fire]]s, with a total area of {{convert|193516|ha|km2|abbr=on}}, in which 244 islands of fire were put out, and 290 new fires sprung up.{{cite news|url=http://www.rian.ru/hs_news/20100807/262662791.html|script-title=ru:Свыше 850 природных пожаров бушуют в России|date=7 August 2010|publisher=RIA Novosti|language=Russian|accessdate=7 August 2010}} In Moscow, by noon the concentration of airborne pollutants intensified and reached at 6.6 times normal level for [[carbon monoxide]], and 2.2 times for [[suspended particulate matter]].{{cite news|url=http://www.rian.ru/hs_news/20100807/262706202.html|script-title=ru:Концентрация угарного газа в Москве превышает ПДК более чем в 6,5 раза|date=7 August 2010|publisher=RIA Novosti|language=Russian|accessdate=7 August 2010}} Seven flights heading for Domodedovo and Vnukovo airports were redirected to alternative airfields.{{cite news|url=http://www.rian.ru/hs_news/20100807/262661210.html|script-title=ru:Семь авиарейсов не смогли сесть во Внуково и Домодедово|date=7 August 2010|publisher=RIA Novosti|language=Russian|accessdate=7 August 2010}} The temperature may have reached {{convert|40|°C|°F}} in Moscow Oblast.{{cite news|url=http://www.itar-tass.com/eng/level2.html?NewsID=15385787&PageNum=0 |title=Still hard to breathe in Moscow because of smog, tmp to rise to 40 |date=7 August 2010 |publisher=ITAR-TASS |accessdate=7 August 2010 }}{{dead link|date=June 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At [[Sheremetyevo International Airport]], [[visibility]] was reduced to 325 meters. ===8 August=== Smoke from fires in the Novgorod region travel north, arriving in Saint Petersburg.{{cite web|url=http://www.internovosti.ru/text/?id=29090|title=Смог охватил Санкт-Петербург|publisher=Internovosti.ru|date=29 October 2009|accessdate=10 August 2010}} ===10 August=== Early in the afternoon of 10 August [[Greenpeace|Greenpeace Russia]] stated that fires were raging in radioactive polluted areas near [[Bryansk]], which is quite polluted due to the [[Chernobyl disaster]] of 1986. This area is still heavily contaminated and has no inhabitants. In the Moscow area a heavy thunderstorm broke over the city. NO2 rates decreased from 8 times normal to normal NO2 rates. Unfortunately expectations are not favorable with temperatures over 35 degrees Celsius. Experts stated that the polluted air would continue again within a few days. Environmental scientists stated that the [[brown cloud]] produced by the fires may cause [[soot]] to land on [[Arctic sea ice]], causing faster melting. The release of industrial [[polychlorinated biphenyls]] from the fires and [[cryoconite]] causing melting on the [[Greenland Ice Sheet]] were also concerns.{{cite news|last=Doyle|first=Alister|title=Russia fires cause "brown cloud", may hit Arctic|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE67937Y20100810|accessdate=22 August 2010|newspaper=Reuters|date=10 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100815024101/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSTRE67937Y20100810| archivedate= 15 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===12 August=== With the number of fires being reduced from 612 to 562, the skies over Moscow were mostly clear on 12 August, giving the city a much needed break from the devastating smog. Residents in the city told reporters that they were overjoyed with the suddenly improved air; most of whom stopped wearing their masks as the air was safe to breathe. However, forecasts indicated that a shift in the winds was likely to occur in the coming days, likely bringing the smog back into Moscow.{{cite news|author=Vladimir Isachenkov |agency=Associated Press |date=12 August 2010 |accessdate=12 August 2010 |title=Smoke-shrouded Moscow gets welcome break from smog |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HHU9T80 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rvuJSMdS?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HHU9T80 |archivedate=12 August 2010 |df=dmy }} Reports indicated that roughly 80,000 hectares of land were still burning.{{cite news|author=Associated Press|publisher=CBC News|date=12 August 2010|accessdate=12 August 2010|title=Moscow skies clear of smog|url=http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/08/12/russia-fires-break-weather.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100815074431/http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2010/08/12/russia-fires-break-weather.html| archivedate= 15 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Press reports stated that a preliminary estimate of damage to the Russian economy as a result of the fires was €11.4 billion ($15 billion).{{cite web|author=Rose Griffin|work=The Irish Times |date=11 August 2010|accessdate=12 August 2010|title=700 dying each day due to Moscow heatwave|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0811/1224276546360.html| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100811000741/http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/world/2010/0811/1224276546360.html| archivedate= 11 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} ===13 August=== [[File:Forest fire near Roshal town 13 aug 2010.JPG|thumb|Front end of forest forest-peat fire fighting near [[Roshal (town)|Roshal town]] ([[Shatursky District|Shatursky district]]) on 13 August 2010.]] After weeks without rain, heavy downpours soaked Moscow and nearby areas, bringing further relief to the extended heat wave. However, in Sarov, about {{convert|480|km|mi}} east of Moscow, a new fire started near the country's top nuclear research center. Earlier in August, radioactive and explosive materials were moved out of the facility due to the threat of fires; however, they were later returned when the threat lessened.{{cite news|author=Vladimir Isachenkov |agency=Associated Press |date=13 August 2010 |accessdate=13 August 2010 |title=Rain refreshes Moscow, but wildfires still burning |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HIM7A01 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxQNQbrN?url=http://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HIM7A01 |archivedate=13 August 2010 |df=dmy }} Over 3,400 firefighters were battling the blaze and were being assisted by a special firefighting train.{{cite web|author=Agence-France-Presse |work=The Standard |location=Hong Kong |date=13 August 2010 |accessdate=13 August 2010 |title=Fires stoke nuclear fears |url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat%3D6%26art_id%3D101687%26sid%3D29245399%26con_type%3D1%26d_str%3D20100813%26fc%3D7 |archive-url=https://www.webcitation.org/5rxQYexB8?url=http://www.thestandard.com.hk/news_detail.asp?we_cat=6&art_id=101687&sid=29245399&con_type=1&d_str=20100813&fc=7 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=13 August 2010 |df= }} ===2 September=== A new wave of wildfires flared up in Russia in September, killing at least 8 people and destroying nearly 900 buildings.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} ==Public health effects== [[File:Цфо обновленный31072010.png|thumb|Temperatures on 31 July 2010.]] Deaths in Moscow were averaged 700 a day, about twice the average number.{{cite news|last=Isachenkov|first=Vladimir|title=Moscow deaths double amid smog to 700 people a day|url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HFVR4G0|accessdate=10 August 2010|newspaper=The Associated Press|date=9 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100815073533/https://www.google.com/hostednews/ap/article/ALeqM5iX-16FttPkCulMdckFjFJyOJCXlAD9HFVR4G0| archivedate= 15 August 2010 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3932560,00.html|title=Moscow deaths double amid smog to 700 people a day – Israel News, Ynetnews|publisher=Ynetnews.com|date=20 June 1995|accessdate=10 August 2010}} The heat wave is believed to have been unprecedented in Russian history, and killed 55,736 people, according to the Centre for Research on the Epidemiology of Disasters.{{cite web|title=2010 Disasters in Numbers|url=http://cred.be/sites/default/files/PressConference2010.pdf|publisher=CRED|accessdate=18 February 2011}} Fires have affected areas contaminated by the [[Chernobyl incident]], specifically the surroundings of [[Bryansk]] and border regions with [[Belarus]] and [[Ukraine]]. Due to this, soil and plant particles contaminated by [[radioactivity|radioactive material]] could be released into the air and spread over wider areas.{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5890452,00.html |author=[[Deutsche Welle]] |title=Russian fires hit Chernobyl-affected areas, threatening recontamination |date=11 August 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100815211432/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0%2C%2C5890452%2C00.html |archivedate=15 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} The Russian government indicated that there had been no discernible increase in [[radiation]], even though [[Greenpeace]] accuses the government of denial. [[France]]'s [[Institut de radioprotection et de sûreté nucléaire]] (Radioprotection and Nuclear Safety Institute) issued its own analysis on 12 August, and concluded that there was no health risk at the time, but that marginally elevated levels of radiation may be detected in the future.{{cite web|url=http://www.irsn.fr/EN/news/Pages/20100812_forest-fires-in-russia.aspx#topPage |title=Questions raised by the forest fires in Russia|publisher=Irsn.fr|accessdate=14 August 2010}} ==International assistance and response== Russia received assistance in extinguishing the fires from [[China]],http://www.china.org.cn/world/2010-08/11/content_20685684.htm [[Serbia]],[http://www.srbija.gov.rs/vesti/vest.php?id=136794 Србија понудила помоћ Русији у гашењу пожара][http://www.glassrbije.org/C/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=56472&Itemid=26 Марић: Србија понудила Русији помоћ у гашењу пожара ] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110721094245/http://www.glassrbije.org/C/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=56472&Itemid=26 |date=21 July 2011 }} [[Italy]],[http://63.mchs.gov.ru/news/detail.php?news=3324 К тушению природных пожаров приступили два итальянских экипажа Р-180, а также вертолет Ми-171т. республики Казахстан.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810205644/http://63.mchs.gov.ru/news/detail.php?news=3324 |date=10 August 2011 }} (''By fighting wildland fires started by two Italian F-180 crew, as well as Mi-171t. Republic of Kazakhstan.'', 7 August 2010) Ukraine,[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/77209/ Ukrainian rescuers helping extinguish forest fires in Russia], [[Kyiv Post]] (6 August 2010) [[Belarus]], [[Armenia]], [[Kazakhstan]], [[Azerbaijan]], [[Bulgaria]], [[Poland]],{{cite web|url=http://www.vz.ru/society/2010/8/5/423281.html|title=ВЗГЛЯД / Флаги в помощь |publisher=Vz.ru|date=8 May 2010|accessdate=7 August 2010}} [[Lithuania]],{{cite web|url=http://rus.ruvr.ru/2010/08/05/14701994.html|title=Литва предлагает России помощь в ликвидации последствий пожаров: Голос России|publisher=Rus.ruvr.ru|accessdate=7 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100812060008/http://rus.ruvr.ru/2010/08/05/14701994.html| archivedate= 12 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Iran,http://fwnews.ru/interesnoe/2iran-pomozhet-tushit-prirodnye-pozhary87 [[Estonia]],{{cite web|url=http://www.izvestia.ru/news/news247391 |title=Известия.Ру: Эстония готова помочь России в борьбе с лесными пожарами |publisher=Izvestia.ru |accessdate=7 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807073152/http://www.izvestia.ru/news/news247391 |archivedate=7 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }} [[Uzbekistan]],{{cite web|url=http://er.ru/about/text.shtml?14/8763|title=Узбекистан предложил РФ помощь в тушении пожаров |publisher=ER.ru|accessdate=7 August 2010}} [[Venezuela]],{{cite web|url=http://www.vz.ru/news/2010/8/5/423486.html|title=ВЗГЛЯД / Венесуэла предложила России помощь в борьбе с пожарами|publisher=Vz.ru|date=8 May 2010|accessdate=7 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100823141819/http://vz.ru/news/2010/8/5/423486.html| archivedate= 23 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} [[France]],{{cite web|url=http://www.tatar-inform.ru/news/2010/08/05/230926 |title=Франция предлагает России помощь в борьбе с пожарами |publisher=Tatar-inform.ru |accessdate=7 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120304005151/http://www.tatar-inform.ru/news/2010/08/05/230926/ |archivedate=4 March 2012 |df= }} [[Germany]],{{cite web|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,5854850,00.html |title=Германия готова помочь России в борьбе с пожарами | Германия | Deutsche Welle | 31.07.2010 |publisher=Dw-world.de |accessdate=7 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100805064136/http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0%2C%2C5854850%2C00.html |archivedate=5 August 2010 |deadurl=no |df=dmy-all }} [[Latvia]]{{cite web|url=http://www.delfi.lv/news/national/politics/krievija-ludz-latvijas-palidzibu-cinai-ar-uguni.d?id=33447827|title=Krievija lūdz Latvijas palīdzību cīņai ar uguni|publisher=Delfi.lv|date=9 August 2010|accessdate=9 August 2010|language=lv}} and [[Finland]]{{cite web|author=[[Foreign Ministry of Finland]]|date=11 August 2010|url=http://www.formin.fi/public/default.aspx?contentid=198322&nodeid=15145&contentlan=2&culture=en-US|title=Finland offers Russia assistance to fight forest fires – Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland: Current affairs|publisher=formin.fi|accessdate=3 November 2010}} Many diplomats and a number of embassies temporarily closed, among them those of [[Austria]], [[Canada]], Germany, Poland and [[Norway]].{{cite web|url=http://nyhederne.tv2.dk/article/32796800/?rss |author=Ritzau |title=Moscow: Smoke closes Norwegian embassy |language=Danish |date=11 August 2010 |accessdate=11 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110719133209/http://nyhederne.tv2.dk/article/32796800/?rss |archivedate=19 July 2011 |df= }} On its website, the [[United States Department of State]] advised Americans traveling to Moscow and surrounding areas should "carefully consider" their plans because of "hazardous levels of [[air pollution]]" and "numerous flight delays". Italy's Foreign Ministry advised people to "postpone any travel plans to Moscow that aren’t strictly necessary".{{Citation needed|date=December 2010}} ==Volunteer efforts== [[File:Volunteers in forest near Roshal town 14 aug 2010.JPG|thumb|Volunteers near the town of [[Roshal (town)|Roshal]] ([[Shatursky District|Shatursky district]] on 14 August 2010 sawed through burnt forest, cleared debris and extinguished small fires.]] Volunteers took part in [[firefighting]] and helping those affected by the fires. In some cases, informal help was faster and more effective than official help.[http://michael-077.livejournal.com/119937.html Главное — решение об организации в Колионово перевалочного пункта гуманной помощи для погорельцев оказалось правильным.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110821214046/http://michael-077.livejournal.com/119937.html |date=21 August 2011 }} (''The decision to organize in [[Kolionovo]] staging point for humanitarian aid to victims of the fire proved correct ... in the [[:ru:Белоомут|Beloomut]] club all rooms littered with mountains of old clothes and shoes. It is not demand. People are grateful, but ask not to bring.'')[http://michael-077.livejournal.com/121213.html Про будни и про рядовой караул пожарной части] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110821214154/http://michael-077.livejournal.com/121213.html |date=21 August 2011 }}(''About firehouse's weekdays and common guard ... They asked about the gloves and mittens ...These people now day after day are at the front of the fire fighting. Several people were killed. Payments of insurance in this case — 36 thousand rubles.'') Volunteers bought and transported fire suppression materials, [[chainsaw]]s, engine-driven water [[pump]]s, [[respirator]]s, food, soap, and drinking water. Volunteer coordination happened via [[LiveJournal]] communities, the main one being ''pozar_ru''.[http://community.livejournal.com/pozar_ru/ Пожар_ру. Благотворительная помощь пострадавшим от пожаров в России] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100807100517/http://community.livejournal.com/pozar_ru/ |date=7 August 2010 }} (''Pozhar_ru. Charitable aid to victims of fires in Russia'') There is also a website ''Russian-fires.ru'' working on [[Ushahidi]] platform that was used at Haiti and Chile earthquakes to coordinate volunteers.[http://russian-fires.ru Карта Помощи пострадавшим от лесных пожаров 2010 в России] (''Help Map for victims of the 2010 forest fires in Russia'')[http://ottenki-serogo.livejournal.com/186701.html Карта Помощи. ''Help Map''] ''[[The Moscow Times]]'' wrote on 17 August 2010:
Volunteers, widely snubbed by professional firefighters because of their lack of experience, have saved several villages by using basic shovels and buckets of water and sand. Even after a larger fire is suppressed with a fire hose, the [[underbrush]] often continues to burn, and a gust of wind can ignite it into a blaze once again. Using shovels and water backpacks, volunteers in Yuvino isolated burning [[groundcover]], cleared a fire line around the village, and loaned firefighters a pump to fill their trucks.[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/news/article/volunteers-take-fires-into-own-hands/412473.htm "Volunteers Take Fires Into Own Hands" by Maria Antonova, ''The Moscow Times'', 17 August 2010]
===Volunteer casualties=== One volunteer died in action in the [[Lukhovitsy]] District on 29 July 2010; the body was found on 15 August 2010.[http://lifenews.ru/news/34770 В Луховицах найдено тело тракториста, пропавшего во время тушения лесного пожара.] (''In [[Lukhovitsy]] found the body of the tractor driver, who disappeared while fighting a forest fire. '') [[LifeNews]]. Another volunteer died in [[Mordovia]] from [[carbon monoxide]] [[carbon monoxide poisoning|poisoning]] on 4 August 2010; the body was found by Police patrol days later.[http://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=385816&cid=8 Вести.Ru: В Мордовии при тушении лесного пожара погиб доброволец] ''one volunteer died in [[Mordovia]], while extinguishing a forest fire''[http://rt.com/Top_News/2010-08-14/fire-russia-smog-moscow.html] Another volunteer died in a car crash in the [[Shatursky District]] on 14 August 2010.[http://community.livejournal.com/pozar_ru/206382.html Погибла Самоварщикова Ольга (in Russian)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100819000616/http://community.livejournal.com/pozar_ru/206382.html |date=19 August 2010 }} ==Censorship== Local Russian commercial and governmental mass media did not provide real-time information for the general public. In the case of a fast-moving [[wildfire]] there would be no chance to inform people via mass media about emergency evacuation. Furthermore, there was no official of [[Dmitry Medvedev|Medvedev's]] administration personally responsible for providing emergency information of this kind.[http://evgen2.livejournal.com/66501.html "В администрации президента никто персонально не отвечает"] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120722174627/http://evgen2.livejournal.com/66501.html |date=22 July 2012 }} (in Russian) In a piece under his byline on the ''[[Moscow Times]]'' website, "Right Cause" party co-founder [[Georgy Bovt]] wrote:
State-controlled television revealed as little information as possible to the public about the fires and smog. Its primary goal was to prevent panic. This eerily reminded me of how the Soviet government reacted to the [[Chernobyl]] explosion in April 1986. In a similar manner, the authorities withheld information about the extent of the nuclear fallout to “avoid panic".[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/opinion/article/putins-vertical-power-disaster/412296.html "Putin's Vertical Power Disaster" by Georgy Bovt, ''The Moscow Times'', 13 August 2010]
In some cases, no information about villages affected by wildfire was available for two weeks.[http://www.vesti.ru/doc.html?id=385249 О сгоревшей деревне Александровке узнали только спустя 2 недели (in Russian)] Doctors from several medical institutions in Moscow, interviewed by an [[Interfax]] correspondent, acknowledged that medical professionals were now forbidden to make a diagnosis of "[[Heat illness|thermal shock]]".[http://www.interfax.ru/society/news.asp?id=149306 В Москве врачам запретили ставить диагноз "тепловой удар" (in Russian)] According to a ''[[Vedomosti]]'' poll on information about the fires in the newspapers, 68% of people said that they trusted online media such as [[blogs]], 28% independent media, and only 4% government media.[http://www.vedomosti.ru/poll/opinions/48/748 Какому источнику информации о пожарах в Центральной России Вы больше доверяете? "Which source of information about fires in central Russia you most trust?", 4 August 2010] Government [[Radio Mayak]] broadcast on 13 August:
Vice-minister of [[Ministry of Emergency Situations (Russia)|Ministry of Emergency Situations]] Alexander Chupriyan said on Friday (13 August 2010) that the peat fires were extinguished completely in the [[Noginsk]], [[Kolomna]], [[Pavlovsky Posad]] and [[Orekhovo-Zuyevo]] areas near Moscow.[http://www.radiomayak.ru/doc.html?id=197924 14 August 2010 11:55 "радио "Маяк" Помощь добровольцев для тушения пожаров больше не требуется] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110928113842/http://www.radiomayak.ru/doc.html?id=197924 |date=28 September 2011 }}
A volunteer wrote about the same events on 13 August 2010 in the [[Orekhovo-Zuyevo]] area in his blog:
I have never seen such...Along the roads—the burned forest. Here and there still smoldering, smoking. The road blocks smoke. What you saw in Moscow — it is nothing you have seen.[http://dimastiy.livejournal.com/237449.html Пока сделали два рейса. "Я такого никогда не видел ..." (с) Вдоль дорог — сгоревший лес. Кое-где еще тлеет, дымится. Периодически дорогу перекрывает дым. То, что вы видели в Москве — это вы ничего не видели.] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110814160344/http://dimastiy.livejournal.com/237449.html |date=14 August 2011 }}
Independent radio [[:ru:Русская служба новостей|РСН]] on 14 August:
The [[Ministry of Emergency Situations (Russia)|MOE]] said that nothing is burning...TV show that nothing is burning...Civilians forced to buy fire equipment for firemen ... I saw open fire at [[Orekhovo-Zuyevo]] area.Radio [[:Русская служба новостей|РСН]] [https://archive.is/20120904214042/http://www.moskva.fm/play/4003/1281769439 Игорь Черский и позвонившие в эфир волонтеры — о ситуации на местах — РСН, 14 августа ''Igor Cherskii and callers on the air volunteer information about the situation on the ground''] (in Russian)
Another volunteer wrote about the events on 15 August 2010 in the same [[Orekhovo-Zuyevo]] area in his blog:
The situation in [[Orekhovo-Zuyevo|Orekhovo]] is stable, i.e. a stable grassroots fire.[https://archive.is/20120711072242/http://community.livejournal.com/pozar_ru/208102.html Новости из Орехово-Зуево], News from [[Orekhovo-Zuyevo]] 15 August 2010
==Russian policies== The [[swamps]] and bogs surrounding Moscow had been drained in the 1960s for agricultural use and mining of [[peat]] to generate energy. In 2002, a series of hard-to-extinguish peat fires led the government to recognize that the peat fields needed to be re-watered to prevent wildfires.{{cite web|url=http://wildfiremag.com/tactics/russia_institutes_peat |author=Serghey Stelmakovich |title=Russia institutes peat fire prevention program |accessdate=9 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100618114909/http://wildfiremag.com/tactics/russia_institutes_peat/ |archivedate=18 June 2010 |df= }} By 2010, however, large expanses of peat areas had not been rewatered and were kindling wildfires. Government officials said they could not have anticipated the heatwave, but critics blamed complacent officials for ignoring warnings of blazes near villages.{{cite news|author=Tom Parfitt in Moscow|url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2010/aug/06/russia-fires-moscow|title=Smoke from Russian fires blankets Moscow | World news|work=[[The Guardian]] |location=London |accessdate=10 August 2010|date=6 August 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20100816034053/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2010/aug/06/russia-fires-moscow| archivedate= 16 August 2010 | deadurl= no}} Sergey Robaten, Vadim Tatur, and Maksim Kalashnikov argued that the fires and the inability to contain and extinguish them was due to "the inaction of bureaucrats" and Putin's elimination of the [[Russian State Fire Service]] in 2007. Putin had transferred responsibility for fighting fires to those renting state property and the subjects of the federation, with the assumption that owners or renters would invest in whatever was necessary to prevent forest fires. However, the reality was more complex; Russian companies were seeking to turn a quick profit and thus neglected forest firefighting. Putin's spokesman remarked, "this is a well-functioning system which only needs some minor adjustments".{{cite web|last=Goble |first=Paul |url=http://www.eurasiareview.com/201008076634/putins-destruction-of-forest-service-in-2007-behind-russias-current-fire-disaster.html |title=Putin's Destruction Of Forest Service In 2007 Behind Russia's Current Fire Disaster |publisher=Eurasiareview.com |accessdate=10 August 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100822000638/http://www.eurasiareview.com/201008076634/putins-destruction-of-forest-service-in-2007-behind-russias-current-fire-disaster.html |archivedate=22 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}{{cite news|last=Bryanski|first=Gleb|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/idUKTRE6723BL20100804|title=Opposition says Putin law cripples Russia fire-fighting | Reuters|publisher=Uk.reuters.com|accessdate=10 August 2010|date=4 August 2010}} ==Role in the [[Arab Spring]]== The wildfires destroyed one-third of Russia's [[wheat]] harvest. The [[Russian government]] refused to export the rest of its harvest and set a [[grain]] export ban to fight [[inflation]]. This led to extremely high food prices, which led to panicking on the global markets. Many experts including from the [[International Food Policy Research Institute]] say that the Russian wildfires in summer 2010 played a leading role in triggering the Arab Spring starting in 2010, especially in [[Egyptian Revolution of 2011|Egypt's case]]. Higher food prices helped to make oppression, poverty, and corruption under autocratic leaders even more aching for the local population.http://www.voanews.com/content/article-2011-food-price-spikes-helped-trigger-arab-spring-135576278/149523.htmlhttps://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IzyXYoZbyK4#t=199 Also, as Russia was not even a member of the [[WTO]] at the time, banning exports was not a problem.http://www.oxfam.org/sites/www.oxfam.org/files/rr-impact-russias-grain-export-ban-280611-en.pdf ==See also== * Similar disasters wave]] **[[1997 Southeast Asian haze]] * Weather and climate **[[Climate of Russia]] **[[Global storm activity of mid-2010|Global storm activity of 2010]] **[[Siberian High]] ==References== The number of new [[Psychiatric medication|psychiatric drugs]], and especially [[antidepressants]] on the market in [[Japan]], is significantly less than [[Western world|Western]] countries.<ref>{{cite journal |author=Kanba S |title=Disparities in drug development: the Japanese paradox |journal=J Psychiatry Neurosci |volume=24 |issue=1 |pages=13–4 |date=Jan 1999 |pmid=9987203 |pmc=1188972 |url=http://www.cma.ca/index.cfm/ci_id/12758/la_id/1.htm}}</ref>
One of the biggest barriers to antidepressants coming to the market is that the [[Social welfare in Japan|medical insurance system in Japan is national]], and the authorities are keen to contain a potentially explosive market for drugs like antidepressants that could be used or abused by persons in various forms of distress.<ref name="Sep 2005"/>
Although large [[Epidemiology|epidemiological]] studies have not been done in Japan, it is thought that up to 6 million Japanese suffer from [[major depressive disorder|depression]], with a lifetime prevalence of 13 to 17.3%, which is similar to that seen in Western countries.<ref name="Sep 2005">{{cite journal |author=Berger D |title=Antidepressant clinical development in Japan: Current perspectives and future horizons |journal=Clinical Research Focus |volume=16 |issue=7 |pages=32–5 |date=Sep 2005 |url=http://www.japanpsychiatrist.com/Abstracts/AntiDepJap.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref>
==Market== While the market has seen the entry of the [[selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors]] (SSRIs) [[fluvoxamine]] (Luvox-Fujisawa, Depromel-Meiji Seika), [[paroxetine]] (Paxil-GSK), [[sertraline]] (Zoloft-Pfizer), and the [[Serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor|SNRI]] [[milnacipran]] (Toledomin-Asahi Kasei-Janssen), other antidepressants including [[citalopram]] ([[Cipramil]]/Cipralex-Lundbeck), [[fluoxetine]] (Prozac-Eli Lilly), [[venlafaxine]] (Effexor-Wyeth) and others are either still under investigation in Japan or have dropped their pursuit on gaining entry into the Japanese market.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Berger D, Fukunishi I |title=Psychiatric drug development in Japan |journal=Science|volume=273 |issue=5273 |pages=318–9 |date=Jul 1996 |pmid=8685717 |url=http://www.sciencemag.org/cgi/pmidlookup?view=long&pmid=8685717 |doi=10.1126/science.273.5273.318}}</ref>
Although none of the antidepressants on the market in Japan have been studied using [[Placebo-controlled study|placebo controls]], this had begun to change since the beginning of the 2000s. Prior clinical developments have pitted the new drug against a drug already on the market using a non-inferiority method of comparison, however, this method is known to be subject to placebo effects, e.g. depressive symptoms lifting due to effects other than [[pharmacologic]] drug effect.<ref name="Sep 2005" /> In a randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled study, [[fluvoxamine]] was superior to placebo for [[Generalized anxiety disorder|General Anxiety Disorder]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Asakura|first=Satoshi|last2=Tajima|first2=Osamu|last3=Koyama|first3=Tsukasa|date=2006-03-30|title=Fluvoxamine treatment of generalized social anxiety disorder in Japan: a randomized double-blind, placebo-controlled study|url=https://academic.oup.com/ijnp/article/10/2/263/655972|journal=The International Journal of Neuropsychopharmacology|language=en|volume=10|issue=02|pages=263|doi=10.1017/S1461145706006602|issn=1461-1457}}</ref>
According to a Japanese medical report in 2002, [[Trazodone]] and [[Tricyclic antidepressant|tricyclic antidepressants]] (TCAs) were widely available in Japan while only two [[Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor|SSRIs]] ([[paroxetine]] and [[fluvoxamine]]) were marketed.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.med.or.jp/english/pdf/2002_01/028_033.pdf|title=Drug Therapy for Depression in Japan|last=Kamimura|first=Makoto|last2=Aoba|first2=Anri|date=2002|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> A third [[Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor|SSRI]], [[sertraline]], received approval in April 2006 after over 15 years of clinical trial development in Japan.<ref>[http://www.lifesciencesworld.com/news/view/7395 Life Sciences World - Online resource for biotechnology, pharmaceutical, medical devices and life sciences industries.]</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.pmda.go.jp/files/000153730.pdf|title=FY2006 List of Approved Products: New Drugs|last=|first=|date=2006|website=|publisher=Pharmaceutical and Medical Devices Agency|format=pdf|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
The three most sold antidepressants in Japan were by the end of 2010 were [[paroxetine]] with a value market share of 37%, [[sertraline]] with a share of 20% and [[fluvoxamine]] with a share of 15%.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.asianscientist.com/2011/08/pharma/lundbeck-mochida-mitsubishi-lexapro-escitalopram-japan/|title=Lundbeck Launches Antidepressent Lexapro In Japan|date=2011-08-27|work=Asian Scientist Magazine {{!}} Science, technology and medical news updates from Asia|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
The Japan algorithm for [[mood disorders]]<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Nomura S, Sawamura T, Kobayashi N, Yoshino A |title=Medication algorithm for mood disorders: Present status and future direction in Japan |journal=International Journal of Psychiatry in Clinical Practice |volume=8 |issue=3 |pages=139–45 |date=Sep 2004 |doi=10.1080/13651500410005432 |url=http://www.ingentaconnect.com/content/apl/pcp/2004/00000008/00000003/art00001}}</ref> does not include many of the post-tricyclic antidepressants used as first-line antidepressants in Western countries for almost two decades, and recent studies are still comparing [[Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor|SSRIs]] and [[tricyclic antidepressants]], even though tricyclics are clearly 2nd or 3rd line treatments in the West.<ref>{{cite journal |vauthors=Otsubo T, Akimoto Y, Yamada H |title=A comparative study of the efficacy and safety profiles between fluvoxamine and nortriptyline in Japanese patients with major depression |journal=Pharmacopsychiatry |volume=38 |issue=1 |pages=30–5 |date=Jan 2005 |pmid=15706464 |doi=10.1055/s-2005-837769 |display-authors=etal}}</ref> [[Organon International]] and [[Meiji Seika]] have filed an application for approval of [[mirtazapine]] in Japan, a drug on the market in many Western countries since 1994.<ref>[http://www.medicalnewstoday.com/articles/76057.php#ratethis#ratethis Antidepressant Mirtazapine (Remeron) Submitted For Approval In Japan.]</ref> [[Meiji Seika]] is commercializing [[Mirtazapine|mirtrazapine]](brand name Reflex)<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.meiji.com/global/about-us/corporate-profile/meiji-seika-pharma/business-domain/ethical-pharmaceutical-business/index.html|title=Meiji Seika Pharma Co., Ltd. {{!}} Meiji Holdings|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.meiji.com/global/about-us/research-and-development/pharmaceuticals/|title=Pharmaceuticals {{!}} Meiji Holdings|access-date=2018-09-16|language=en}}</ref> in [[Japan]] which was approved for [[Major depressive disorder|depression]] in 2009.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://mailman.ucsd.edu/pipermail/funding-opportunities-l/attachments/20150311/e41ae7a3/attachment-0001.pdf|title=Meiji Seika Pharma Co., Ltd.|last=|first=|date=2015|website=|publisher=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref>
[[Citalopram]] (Lundbeck), an SSRI on the market since the late 1980s is not available in Japan, however on April 22, 2011 [[escitalopram]] (the S-isomer [[enantiomer]] of [[citalopram]]), was approved for use in Japan.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/04/22/lundbeck-japan-idUSLDE73L03X20110422 | work=Reuters | first=Mette | last=Fraende | title=Lundbeck gets Lexapro approval in Japan | date=April 22, 2011}}</ref> There is little news, however, on the status of [[bupropion]] ([[GlaxoSmithKline|Glaxo Smith-Kline]]), used widely in Western countries since the early 1990s and long in clinical trials in Japan.
==References== {{reflist|2}}

== Further reading ==
* Higuchi, Briley, 2007. ''[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2654524/ Japanese experience with milnacipran, the first serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor in Japan]''
[[Category:Drugs in Japan]] [[Category:Antidepressants]]

'''Armenicum''' is a drug invented in [[Armenia]] in 1998 that its developers claim is an effective treatment for [[HIV]] infection and a number of associated diseases. No rigorously monitored clinical trials of Armenicum have been published, and most HIV experts outside of Armenia do not endorse its use.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/564867.stm|title=Scepticism over Aids 'cure'|last=|first=|date=|website=BBC News|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref>
In 1999, a [[BBC]] investigation involving interviews with scientists involved in administering the drug, patients and creator [[Alexander Ilyen]] raised serious doubts about the drug's efficacy, concluding that Armenicum might do more harm than good. Dr. [[Manfred Dietrich]] of the [[Institute for Tropical Medicine]] in [[Hamburg]] told the BBC "I would not recommend at all to take such a drug." while an American patient said "we’re in a worse state than we were before we went." <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/sci_tech/highlights/000720_armenicum.shtml|title=Access Armenicum|last=|first=|date=20 July 2000|website=BBC World Service|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-06-21}}</ref>
Worldwide, the most effective treatment for HIV are antiretroviral drugs, which in internationally accepted clinical trials have been the only proven way to keep patients alive, often for years. The drugs work by directly attacking and reducing the amount of HIV in the body, keeping the patient from developing Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome (AIDS), a complete immune system failure that leads to death. The drugs, offered in cocktails of three or four at a time, are often changed as the virus becomes resistant.
Alternatively, the makers of Armenicum claim it boosts the immune system, allowing the body to fight the virus. Armenicum clinic doctors also contend the drug has been shown to reduce a patient’s viral load—the amount of HIV in the body—and that HIV never becomes resistant to it. The problem is that company scientists have never tried to prove any of these claims. They admit to not even formally monitoring the 250 patients who have been treated with the drug during the period from 2004 to 2008.<ref name="eur">{{Cite news|url=http://www.eurasianet.org/departments/insightb/articles/eav112508.shtml|title=Ten Years On, Armenia's So-Called "Miracle Cure" for AIDS Still Unproven|last=Khojoyan|first=Sara|date=2008-11-24|work=EurasiaNet|access-date=2017-06-21|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|last2=Kohlenberg|first2=Leah}}</ref>
The main ingredient of Armenicum is [[iodine]], a general [[antiseptic]]. According to the manufacturers it also contains [[dextrin]], [[polyvinyl alcohol]], [[sodium]], [[potassium]] and [[lithium]] cations and [[chloride]] anions. It is described as a "blue-violet liquid with specific odor, packed in orange glass bottles per 20ml and corked tightly by a rubber plug clutched by aluminum caps."<ref>[http://www.armenicum.am/instruction.html ARMENICUM is a highly promising drug for treatment of HIV infection and AIDS<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081205051229/http://www.armenicum.am/instruction.html |date=December 5, 2008 }}</ref>
When Armenicum was first introduced in Armenia in 1998, founders called it a "revolutionary cure for AIDS," and it immediately captured Armenia's high-ranking government officials’ interest. Early on, initial payments for Armenicum treatments came from the Armenian Defense Ministry, hoping to promote the drug’s research and development. Armenicum’s possibilities caused a buzz of excitement in the tiny country. Businessmen, it was reported in some newspapers in 1999, were buying up property so that they could rent it to all the people who would fly to Armenia to take the cure. However, as of November 2008, only about 800 people have taken Armenicum, which is financed by the Armenian government at a cost of around $6,000 per patient per year.<ref name="eur"/>
==Kolesnikov Controversy== On 8 September 2000, Nikolai Kolesnikov, who had received treatment for AIDS in "Armenicum" center in Armenia was reported dead in one of [[Kaliningrad]] hospitals. According to his doctors, Armenicum turned out to be a simple immunity modular, without any effect on the virus which continues to damage the cells in the human body.<ref>[http://www.asbarez.com/2000/09/08/patient-treated-with-armenicum-dies/ Patient Treated With Armenicum Dies]. Asbarez.com, September 8, 2000</ref>
In March 2005 Kolesnikov was reported to have frozen to death in his native Kaliningrad. There have been several other reports on his death over the years.<ref>[http://www.armradio.am/news/?part=soc&id=2124 Nikolay Kolesnikov Dead Having Reportedly Frozen To Death]. Public Radio of Armenia, March 19, 2005 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110531152904/http://www.armradio.am/news/?part=soc&id=2124 |date=May 31, 2011 }}</ref>

==Sources== *[http://www.armenicum.am/ Armenicum website] *[http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/health/564867.stm Scepticism over Aids 'cure'] *[http://www.bbc.co.uk/worldservice/sci_tech/highlights/000720_armenicum.shtml Access Armenicum]

{{Infobox medical intervention | name = Auditory-verbal therapy | synonym = | image = | caption = | alt = | pronounce = | specialty = ENT/audiologist | synonyms = | ICD10 = | ICD9 = | ICD9unlinked = | CPT = | MeshID = | LOINC = | other_codes = | MedlinePlus = | eMedicine = }} '''Auditory-verbal therapy''' is a method for teaching [[hearing impairment|deaf]] [[children]] to [[Wiktionary:listen|listen]] and [[speech|speak]] using their residual hearing in addition to the constant use of amplification devices such as [[hearing aid]]s, FM devices, and [[cochlear implant]]s. Auditory-verbal therapy emphasizes speech and listening.
Auditory verbal therapy enables deaf and hard of hearing [[children]] to participate more fully in mainstream school and hearing society. In 2006, Rhoades<ref>Rhoades E. (2006) Research Outcomes of Auditory-Verbal Intervention: Is the Approach Justified? Deafness Educ. Int. 8(3), 125–143</ref> published an article looking at whether the Auditory Verbal approach was justified. Using Frattali’s system for weighing the strength of treatment evidence based on the degree of scientific rigour, she found 7 studies concerning the AV approach of class II level evidence.<ref>Dornan D, Hickson L, Murdoch B, Houston T, and Constantinescu G. (2010). Is Auditory-Verbal Therapy Effective for Children with Hearing Loss? Volta Rev. 110(3), 361–387 Eriks-Brophy, A. (2004). Outcomes of auditory-verbal therapy: A review of the evidence and a call for action. Volta Rev 104(1), 21–35. </ref><ref>Goldberg DM, Flexer C (September 2001). "Auditory-verbal graduates: outcome survey of clinical efficacy". J Am Acad Audiol 12 (8): 406–14. {{PMID|11599875}}.</ref><ref>Rhoades E, Chisholm T. (2000) Global language progress with an Auditory-Verbal approach for children who are deaf or hard of hearing. Volta Rev. 102, 5–24</ref> She concluded that even with the minimal number of studies, there was evidence "for the validity and effectiveness of the A-V intervention model". Following on from Rhoades’ work, Hogan et al. (2008;<ref>Hogan S, Stokes J, White C, Tyszkiewicz E, Woolgar A. (2008) An evaluation of Auditory Verbal Therapy using rate of early language development as an outcome measure. Deafness Educ Int. 10,143–167</ref> 2010<ref>Hogan S, Stokes J and Weller I. (2010) Language Outcomes for Children of Low-Income Families Enrolled in Auditory Verbal Therapy. Deafness Educ Int. 12 (4) 204-216</ref>) published outcomes for children in an AV programme which were essentially quasi-experimental studies in that the assessment tool used had been standardised on typically developing children and so a comparison could be drawn between the age equivalence scores obtained by the children on the study and their chronological or ‘hearing’ age. (The hearing age of a child is the duration of time since the child has had optimal access to sound.) In these studies, the average rate of language development increased significantly during the time on the programme compared to the average rate of language development prior to embarking on the programme. Dornan et al. (2009)<ref>Dornan D, Hickson L, Murdoch B, Houston T. (2009) Longitudinal study of speech and language for children with hearing loss in Auditory-Verbal Therapy programs. Volta Rev. 109,1–25</ref> reviewed the evidence for Auditory Verbal Therapy and concluded that while it was not possible to demonstrate a cause and effect relationship between the intervention and the outcome, increasing the strength of evidence for outcomes was vital. In 2010, Dornan et al. published a longitudinal study comparing the outcomes of 29 children enrolled on an AV programme with age-matched controls. They found AV to be an effective intervention.
First Voice (a membership body which represents organisations that provide listening and spoken language therapy in Australia and New Zealand) published a study in February 2015 based on information on more than 600 children with hearing loss. When listening and spoken language outcomes of children with a hearing loss were compared to those with typical hearing most children attending AVT had ‘scores within or above the average range for typical hearing children for language (74.4%-75.6%), vocabulary (79.6%) and speech performance (71.5%). When children with additional disabilities were removed from the analysis, the number of children within or above the average range for typical hearing children increased, except for speech performance (language performance=77.9%-80.2%; vocabulary performance= 83.1%; speech performance=73.1%).’ (First Voice, 2015 pp 5).<ref>First Voice (February 2015). "Sound Outcomes: First Voice speech and language data.http://www.firstvoice.org.au/userfiles/file/150302_Sound_Outcomes_First_Voice_Speech_and_Language_Data.pdf</ref>
In the UK, access to auditory verbal therapy is currently available at two cochlear implant centres (Paediatric Cochlear Implant Programme, Manchester Auditory Implant Programme and Midlands Hearing Implant Programme - Children's Service). Outside of the NHS AVT is available via award-winning<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.avuk.org/our-awards|title=Auditory Verbal {{!}} Our awards|website=www.avuk.org|language=en|access-date=2017-01-23}}</ref> national charity [[Auditory Verbal UK|Auditory Verbal<sup>UK</sup> (AV<sup>UK</sup>)]](Oxfordshire and London); The Speech and Hearing and Language Centre, Christopher Place in London; and at the Auditory Verbal Lounge in Nottingham.
==References== <references/>
==Further reading==
* {{cite book |author1=Estabrooks, Warren |author2=MacIver-Lux, Karen |author3=Rhoades, Ellen A. | title=Auditory-Verbal Therapy: For Young Children with Hearing Loss and Their Families, and the Practitioners Who Guide Them | publisher=Plural Publishing | year=2016 | isbn=978-1-59756-888-3}} * Rhoades, EA; Chisholm, TH. (2001). Global language progress with an auditory-verbal approach for children who are deaf or hard of hearing. Volta Review, Volume 102(1), Pgs. 5-25

revision.text:
'''BUKO Pharma-Kampagne''' is an independent organization based in [[Bielefeld]], [[Germany]], which watches over the marketing practices of German pharmaceutical companies.
It has gained wider recognition after being described in a bestselling novel, ''[[The Constant Gardener]]'' by [[John le Carré]]. BUKO was mentioned explicitly in the author's afterword as a real counterpart to the novel's fictitious Hippo organisation (also based in Bielefeld, Germany).
BUKO is partially financed by the [[European Union]] and mostly by private supporters.
==See also== *''[[The Constant Gardener (film)|The Constant Gardener]]'' – the movie (2005) by [[Fernando Meirelles]] *[[World Health Organization]] Research [http://www.who.int/ethics/research/en/ Ethics Review Committee]
==References== *[http://www.bukopharma.de BUKO Homepage] *[http://www.haiweb.org Health Action International]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Buko Pharma-Kampagne}} [[Category:Pharmaceutical industry]] [[Category:Medical and health organisations based in North Rhine-Westphalia]]

revision.text:
Injuries in [[rock climbing]] may occur due to falls, or due to overuse (see [[Sports injury]]). Injuries due to falls are relatively uncommon; the vast majority of injuries result from overuse, most often occurring in the fingers, elbows, and shoulders.<ref>{{cite book |title=Training for Climbing: The Definitive Guide to Improving Your Climbing |last=Hörst |first=Eric J. |authorlink=|coauthors= |year=2003 |publisher=Falcon Publishing |location=Guilford, Connecticut, Helena, Montana |isbn=0-7627-2313-0 |page=151 |pages= |url=http://www.trainingforclimbing.com/ |accessdate=}}</ref> Such injuries are often no worse than torn [[callus]]es, cuts, burns and bruises. However, overuse symptoms, if ignored, may lead to permanent damage (esp. to [[tendon]]s, [[tendon sheath]]s, [[ligament]]s, and [[joint capsule]]s).
==Risk groups== The climbers most prone to injuries are intermediate to expert within lead climbing or bouldering.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.climbing.com.au/Who%20gets%20injured%20in%20the%20gym.pdf |title=Indoor rock climbing: who gets injured? |last1=Wright |first1=D. M. |last2=Royle |first2=T. J. |last3=Marshall |first3=T |year=2001 |work= |publisher=Br J Sports Med |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
==Overuse injuries in climbing== In terms of overuse injuries a British study found that:<ref>{{cite book |title=The Science of Rock Climbing and Mountaineering |type=A collection of scientific articles |chapter=Injuries and associated training and performance characteristics in recreational rock climbers |last1=article by: Doran |first1=D. A. |last2= Reay |first2=M. |date=2000 |isbn=0-7360-3106-5 |publisher= Human Kinetics Publishing}}</ref> * 40% occurred in the fingers * 16% in the shoulders * 12% in the elbows * 5% in the knees * 5% in the back * 4% in the wrists
One injury that tend to be very common among climbers is [[Carpal tunnel syndrome]]. It is found in about 25% of climbers.<ref name=preston>{{cite web |url=http://www.hughston.com/hha/a.climb.htm |title=Rock Climbing Reaching New Heights |last1=Preston |first1=Dayton |date= |work= |publisher=Hughston health alert|accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
=== Finger injuries === 604 injured rock climbers were prospectively evaluated from January 1998 to December 2001, due to the rapid growth of new complex finger trauma in the mid-1980s. Of the most frequent injuries, three out of four were related to the fingers: pulley injuries accounted for 20%, tendovaginitis for 7%, and joint capsular damage for 6.1%.<ref>{{cite journal |pmid=12825883 |title=Pulley injuries in rock climbers |last1=Schöffl |first1=V. |last2=Hochholzer |first2=T. |last3=Winkelmann |first3=H.P. |last4=Strecker |first4=W. |date=Summer 2003 |work= |publisher=Wilderness & environmental medicine |volume=14 |issue=2 |journal=Wilderness Environ Med |pages=94–100 |doi=10.1580/1080-6032(2003)014[0094:piirc]2.0.co;2}}</ref>
==== Pulleys ==== Damage to the [[flexor tendon pulley]]s that encircle and support the tendons that cross the finger joints is the most common finger injury within the sport (see [[climber's finger]]).<ref name=preston /> The main culprit for pulley related injuries is the common crimp grip, especially in the closed position. The crimp grip requires a near ninety-degree flexion of the middle finger joint, which produces a tremendous force load on the A2 pulley. Injuries to the A2 pulley can range from microscopic to partial tears and, in the worst case, complete ruptures. Some climbers report hearing a pop, which might be a sign of a significant tear or complete rupture, during an extremely heavy move (e.g. tiny crimp, one- or two-finger pocket). Small partial tears, or inflammation can occur over the course of several sessions.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.nicros.com/archive/A2_pulley_injury.cfm |title=Finger Tendon Pulley Injury |last1=Hörst |first1=Eric J |year=2008 |work= |publisher=Nicros |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
* '''Grade I''' – Sprain of the finger ligaments (collateral ligaments), pain locally at the pulley, pain when squeezing or climbing. * '''Grade II''' – Partial rupture of the pulley tendon. Pain locally at the pulley, pain when squeezing or climbing, possible pain while extending your finger. * '''Grade III''' – Complete rupture of the pulley, causing bowstringing of the tendon. Symptoms can include: Pain locally at the pulley (usually sharp), may feel/hear a 'pop' or 'crack', swelling and possible bruising, pain when squeezing or climbing, pain when extending your finger, pain with resisted flexion of the finger.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://climbinginjuries.com/page/fingers |title=DIAGNOSIS: Pulleys |last1=Roseborrough |first1=Aimee |last2=Roseborrough |first2=Kyle |year=2009 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
==== Knuckle ==== *Stress fractures *Collateral ligament injuries
=== Shoulder injuries === Shoulder related injuries include [[rotator cuff]] tear, strain or [[tendinitis]], biceps tendinitis and [[Slap lesion|SLAP lesion]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://climbinginjuries.com/page/shoulders |title=Climbing Injuries: Shoulders |last1=Roseborrough |first1=Aimee |last2=Roseborrough |first2=Kyle |year=2009 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
=== Elbow injuries === [[Tennis elbow]] (Lateral Epicondylitis) is a common elbow injury among climbers, as is [[Golfer's elbow]] (Medial Epicondylitis, which is similar, but occurs on the inside of the elbow).
===Calluses, dry skin=== Climbers often develop calluses on their fingers from regular contact with the rock and the rope. When calluses split open they expose a raw layer of skin that can be very painful. This type of injury is commonly referred to as a flapper.
The use of [[magnesium carbonate]] (chalk) for better grip dries out the skin and can often lead to cracked and damaged hands <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kletterretter.com/en/about-us/ |title=Hand cream for rock climbers |website=Kletter Retter |accessdate=5 February 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150206023238/http://www.kletterretter.com/en/about-us/ |archivedate=February 6, 2015 }}</ref>
There are a number of skincare products available for climbers that help to treat calluses, moisturise dry hands and reduce recovery time.
==Young/adolescent climbers== "Any finger injury that is sustained by a young adolescent (12–16) should be seen by a physician and have x-rays performed. These skeletally immature athletes are very susceptible to developing debilitating joint arthritis later in adulthood."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.athleticadvisor.com/injuries/ue/finger/finger_injuries.htm |title=Finger Injuries |last1=Edell |first1=David |date=24 October 2009 |work= |publisher= |accessdate=11 January 2011}}</ref>
==See also== * Related topics **[[Carpal tunnel syndrome]] **[[Climber's finger]] **[[Golfer's elbow]] **[[Repetitive strain injury]] **[[Radial tunnel syndrome]] **[[Tennis elbow]] * Lists and glossaries ** [[List of climbing topics]] ** [[Climbing terminology]] ** [[Climbing command]]
== References == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Climbing]] [[Category:Rock climbing]] [[Category:Overuse injuries]] [[Category:Sports medicine]] [[Category:Inflammations]] [[Category:Soft tissue disorders]]
