revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=October 2015}} [[Diabetes mellitus|Diabetes]], in particular, non-insulin dependent diabetes, is prevalent in the [[Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people|Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander]] populations of [[Australia]].<ref>{{cite journal|last1=O'Dea|first1=K|title=Diabetes in aboriginal Australians|volume=37|issue=3|pages=25–8|accessdate=31 August 2015}}</ref> As many as 1 in 20<ref name="Diabetes AIHW">{{Cite web|title = Diabetes (AIHW)|url = http://www.aihw.gov.au/diabetes/|website = www.aihw.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref> Australians are said to suffer from diabetes, and of this amount, Aboriginals are three times as likely to succumb to this disease, in comparison to non-Aboriginals.<ref>{{Cite web|title = 4727.0.55.001 - Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Survey: First Results, Australia, 2012-13|url = http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/CD58150AC0A36286CA257C2F0014591C?opendocument|website = www.abs.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref> In contrast with [[Diabetes mellitus type 1|type 1 diabetes]], which is a predisposed autoimmune condition,<ref>{{Cite web|title = Type 1 diabetes|url = https://www.diabetesaustralia.com.au/type-1-diabetes|website = www.diabetesaustralia.com.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref> [[Diabetes mellitus type 2|type 2 diabetes]] or insulin resistant diabetes, is a preventable disease, heavily influenced by a multitude of socioeconomic factors.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Diabetes in australian aboriginal and torres strait islander peoples|author1=Rowley, K. G. |author2=O'Dea, K. |last-author-amp=yes |date = 2001|journal = Papua and New Guinea Medical Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Sufferers of the disease are consequently more susceptible to chronic health issues, including [[heart disease]] and [[renal failure]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|title = Incidence of type 2 diabetes in Aboriginal Australians: an 11-year prospective cohort study|url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1471-2458/10/487/abstract|journal = BMC Public Health|date = 2010-08-17|issn = 1471-2458|pmc = 2931471|pmid = 20712905|pages = 487|volume = 10|issue = 1|doi = 10.1186/1471-2458-10-487|first = Zhiqiang|last = Wang|first2 = Wendy E.|last2 = Hoy|first3 = Damin|last3 = Si}}</ref> Conclusively, this has contributed to the 17 year life expectancy gap between Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals and in turn, has led to disparity and inequity of health between Aboriginals and non-Aboriginals.<ref name=":0" />
== History == The history of Aboriginal Australians is said to have spanned some 60,000 years prior to colonization,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Sydney's Aboriginal Past|last = Attenbrow|first = V|date = 2010|journal = Investigating the Archaeological and Historical Records.|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |pages = 152–153}}</ref> yet they were first cited by Europeans in 1606.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|url = |title = Doing Aboriginal History|last = Broome|first = R|date = 2014|journal = Agora|doi = |pmid = |access-date = |issue = 2|edition = |pages = 40–49}}</ref> Further investigations of the land over the years leading to [[James Cook|James Cook's]] arrival in 1788, suggested that the Aboriginals were hunter gatherers, who were described as beasts who roamed the land.<ref name=":2" /> Fully utilising the resources at their disposal, the diet of the early Aboriginals was predominantly made up of land animals, fish and shellfish, as well as birds and plant foods.<ref name=":1" /> Post colonisation, the Aboriginals experienced excessive disruptions to their socioeconomic circumstances and thus, this has seen a rapid decline in their health status.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|title = Trying to keep a balance: the meaning of health and diabetes in an urban Aboriginal community|url = http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0277953600000460|journal = Social Science & Medicine|date = 2000-11-16|pages = 1457–1472|volume = 51|issue = 10|doi = 10.1016/S0277-9536(00)00046-0|first = Samantha J|last = Thompson|first2 = Sandra M|last2 = Gifford}}</ref> Forced to assimilate into a white, European Society, Aboriginals abandoned their traditional way of living and reluctantly adopted those of the colony.<ref name=":3" /> Over time this has seen the introduction of sugar and refined foods into the diet of Aboriginal Australians, initially to sever existing connections to the land.<ref name=":3" /> Aboriginals have since viewed sugar as an important cultural food, bringing with it, family identities and reinforcing connections.<ref name=":3" /> Hence, Aboriginals have since become highly vulnerable to suffering from conditions such as diabetes.
== Causes ==
=== European influence === The prevalence of type 2 diabetes, obesity and the corresponding diseases that are associated with this condition, are often attributed to the European influences at the time of colonisation.<ref name="Daniel">{{Cite journal|title = Diabetes and impaired glucose tolerance in Aboriginal Australians: prevalence and risk|url = http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0168822702000062|journal = Diabetes Research and Clinical Practice|date = 2002-01-01|volume = 57|issue = 1|doi = 10.1016/s0168-8227(02)00006-2|first = M.|last = Daniel|first2 = K.G.|last2 = Rowley|first3 = R.|last3 = McDermott|first4 = K.|last4 = O'Dea}}</ref> Sugar and refined foods were used at this time as a means of detaching Aboriginals from the land and assimilating them into white society. Consequently, Aboriginal Australians have likened certain traditions and memories to the use of sugar. Thus, the ‘westernisation’ of Aboriginal communities forced the neglect of a nutrient-dense diet and thus, cemented the foundation for this prevailing condition.
=== Remoteness === Remoteness of Aboriginal communities and disparity in socioeconomic circumstances has also contributed to the prevalence of diabetes in Aboriginal Australians. Consequently, refined foods have seemingly replaced healthy alternatives, as communities are denied access to fresh and healthy foods due to limited available resources.<ref name="King 147–155">{{Cite journal|title = The diabetes health care of Aboriginal people in South Australia (Part 1)|url = https://dx.doi.org/10.5172/conu.10.3-4.147|journal = Contemporary Nurse|date = 2001-06-01|issn = 1037-6178|pages = 147–155|volume = 10|issue = 3-4|doi = 10.5172/conu.10.3-4.147|first = Merilyn|last = King}}</ref> Similarly, many Aboriginals are said to live in poverty, with community’s dependant on welfare and most being plagued by unemployment. Thus, recognising their need to be frugal with their money, and in turn, only being able to afford energy dense, filling foods, which are often high in fats and sugar.<ref>{{Cite journal|url = |title = Diabetes in Indigenous Australians: possible ways forward|author1=Brown, A. |author2=O'Dea, K. |author3=Rowley, K.G. |date = 2007|journal = The Medical Journal of Australia|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> Hence, there is a direct correlation between the disparity of wealth, obesity and subsequent morbidity. Consequently, this is a main contributor to Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders being 2-4 more times likely to suffer from this condition.<ref name=":14" />
=== Health inequalities === Health inequalities in society and lack of education can also contribute to the higher diagnosis of diabetes among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders.<ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|title = Characteristics and outcome of type 2 diabetes in urban Aboriginal people: the Fremantle Diabetes Study|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1445-5994.2006.01247.x/abstract|journal = Internal Medicine Journal|date = 2007-01-01|issn = 1445-5994|pages = 59–63|volume = 37|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/j.1445-5994.2006.01247.x|first = T. M. E.|last = Davis|first2 = D.|last2 = McAullay|first3 = W. A.|last3 = Davis|first4 = D. G.|last4 = Bruce}}</ref>
=== Unutilised resources === Similarly, Aboriginal people are recognised as not utilising the health resources at their disposal.<ref name="King 147–155"/> As a result, Australian Aboriginals are said to be lacking in diabetes education and the subsequent monitoring of glucose levels,<ref name=":14"/> making them more susceptible to diabetes related problems as well as lack of educational knowledge and ill-informed in making decisions in regards to their health.
=== Low birth weights === Aboriginal infants are also said to have relatively lower birth weights than normal, which can also contribute to early incidences of type 2 diabetes.<ref name=":14"/>
=== Lifestyle === As well as being genetically predisposition are found commonly in young-onset diabetic patients. Diabetes is not a single gene disease, autoimmunity, rare gene variants and a common variant may be present in a single individual. type 2 diabetes is also associated with obesity and other cardiovascular factors and lifestyle influences.<ref name=":7">Rosenberg M, Lawrence A. Review of primary prevention of type 2 diabetes in Western Australia. [cited 2006 March]. Available from URL: http://www.health.wa.gov.au/publications/documents/9755type2diabetesreview.pdf</ref> Thus, those with high blood pressure, a poor diet, insufficient physical activity and are overweight/ obese, and in the case of Aboriginal Australians, are over the age of 35, are increasingly more susceptible to suffering from type 2 diabetes.<ref name=":8">{{Cite web|title = Type 2 diabetes|url = https://www.diabetesaustralia.com.au/type-2-diabetes|website = www.diabetesaustralia.com.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref>
===Pregnancy=== [[Gestational diabetes]] refers to gluten intolerance diabetes diagnosed during pregnancy and is highly common among Aboriginal Australians.<ref name=":5">{{Cite journal |title=The prevalence of gestational diabetes mellitus among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander women in Australia: a systematic review and meta-analysis |url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/dmrr.2570/abstract |journal=Diabetes/Metabolism Research and Reviews |date=2015-03-01 |issn=1520-7560 |pages=234–247 |volume=31 |issue=3 |doi=10.1002/dmrr.2570 |first=Catherine |last=Chamberlain |first2=Grace |last2=Joshy |first3=Hang |last3=Li |first4=Jeremy |last4=Oats |first5=Sandra |last5=Eades |first6=Emily |last6=Banks}}</ref>
== Complications == Type 2 diabetes is a detrimental condition commonly affecting Aboriginal Australians. It is closely associated with obesity and is often a precursor for subsequent preventable diseases, including cardiovascular and renal disease. Hence, diabetes is a major cause of the premature mortality of many Aboriginal Australians.<ref name="Daniel"/>
Increased occurrence of renal complications among Aboriginals is attributed to environmental and genetic factors,<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|url = |title = Placing aboriginal kidney disease in context.|last = McDonald, S.|date = 2014|journal = Canadian Medical Association Journal|doi = |pmid = |access-date = }}</ref> as well as poor monitoring of glucose levels.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Prevalence of treated end-stage kidney disease (ESKD) (AIHW)|url = http://www.aihw.gov.au/diabetes-indicators/prevalence-of-eskd/|website = www.aihw.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref> Low birth weight causing lower renal volume, post infectious renal damage and obesity are also characteristically associated with [[chronic kidney disease]] and end stage renal failure.<ref name=":9" /> Consequently, Australian Aboriginals are 8 times more likely to suffer from incidences of kidney failure than non-Aboriginal Australians.<ref>{{Cite journal|title = The perspectives of Aboriginal patients and their health care providers on improving the quality of hemodialysis services: A qualitative study|url = http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/hdi.12201/abstract|journal = Hemodialysis International|date = 2015-01-01|issn = 1542-4758|pmc = 4309474|pmid = 25056441|pages = 80–89|volume = 19|issue = 1|doi = 10.1111/hdi.12201|first = Elizabeth F.|last = Rix|first2 = Lesley|last2 = Barclay|first3 = Janelle|last3 = Stirling|first4 = Allison|last4 = Tong|first5 = Shawn|last5 = Wilson}}</ref>
Similarly, [[cardiovascular disease]] is the single greatest contributor to the disparity in life expectancy between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal Australians.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|title = Early identification and preventive care for elevated cardiovascular disease risk within a remote Australian Aboriginal primary health care service|url = http://www.biomedcentral.com/1472-6963/11/24/abstract|journal = BMC Health Services Research|date = 2011-01-31|issn = 1472-6963|pmc = 3045287|pmid = 21281520|pages = 24|volume = 11|issue = 1|doi = 10.1186/1472-6963-11-24|first = Christopher P.|last = Burgess|first2 = Ross S.|last2 = Bailie|first3 = Christine M.|last3 = Connors|first4 = Richard D.|last4 = Chenhall|first5 = Robyn A.|last5 = McDermott|first6 = Kerin|last6 = O'Dea|first7 = Charlie|last7 = Gunabarra|first8 = Hellen L.|last8 = Matthews|first9 = Adrian J.|last9 = Esterman}}</ref> Obesity and increased waist circumference is an important risk factor,<ref name=":10" /> along with other modifiable influences including smoking, high blood pressure, high cholesterol levels, low levels of physical activity.<ref name=":10" /> All of which contribute to the incidence of diabetes and consequently, cardiovascular disease.Moreover Gestational Diabetes is also a complication in pregnant women which not not only causes harm to pregnant women but it leads to the birth complication of the fetus as well as it also transfres diabetes to the fetus from mother .
The prevalence of type 2 diabetes in Aboriginal Australians can also lead to retinotherapy, whereby blood vessels in the eye are damaged<ref>{{Cite web|title = Diabetic Retinopathy|url = http://www.visionaustralia.org/eye-health/eye-conditions/diabetic-retinopathy|website = www.visionaustralia.org|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref> as a direct result of this condition. Peripheral neuropathy is also common in diabetes patients and in some cases can lead to chronic foot problems and even amputations.<ref name=":11">{{Cite web|title = Review of diabetes among Indigenous peoples « Reviews « Diabetes « Chronic conditions « Australian Indigenous HealthInfoNet|url = http://www.healthinfonet.ecu.edu.au/chronic-conditions/diabetes/reviews/our-review#fnl-30|website = www.healthinfonet.ecu.edu.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref>
== Prevention == [[File:CSIRO ScienceImage 10461 A selection of fruit and vegetables.jpg|thumb]] Health issues affecting Aboriginal Australians, including the incidence of type 2 diabetes, are often likened to disparities in socioeconomic status.<ref name=":11" /> Often, the greater the social and economic disadvantage, the greater the occurrence of diabetes and other associated conditions.<ref name=":11" /> Thus, improvements in the socioeconomic status and the decrease in disparity and health inequality are detrimental if the incidence of diabetes and the associated conditions are to be reduced.
Early detection programs and diabetes screenings are essential in reducing the frequency of diabetes and its long-term effects.<ref name=":11" /> Moreover regular weight assessment should be done. Promotion of healthy eating and physical activity, smoking cessation and the safe consumption of alcohol<ref name=":12">(2011). ''Diabetes in rural Australia''. [Phamphlet]. Deakin West, Australia: National Rural Health Alliance</ref> are also vital to reduce and prevent type 2 diabetes. The Australian government has addressed the need for such intervention by implementing the National Prevention of Type 2 Diabetes program. Arguably,{{According to whom|date=November 2016}} such programs need to be supported by efforts to provide greater employment and educational opportunities for Aboriginal Australians and health programs tailored to their favoured holistic approach to health and wellbeing.<ref name=":12" />
== Statistics == One in 20 Australian adults had diabetes in 2011–2012.<ref name="Diabetes AIHW"/>
Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are 2–4 times more likely to suffer from diabetes than other non-indigenous groups.<ref name=":14"/>
Evidence of diabetes among Aboriginals is apparent as early as 25 years of age. Approximately 18% of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders over the age of 25 reported having diabetes or high blood sugar levels. The rates range from 5% for those in the 25 years age bracket and increasing to 39% for those aged 55 years and over.<ref name=":13">{{Cite web|title = 4727.0.55.001 - Australian Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Health Survey: First Results, Australia, 2012-13|url = http://www.abs.gov.au/ausstats/abs@.nsf/Lookup/CD58150AC0A36286CA257C2F0014591C?opendocument|website = www.abs.gov.au|accessdate = 2015-09-03}}</ref>
In 2012–2013, approximately 8% of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders reported that they had diabetes or high blood sugar levels. Females were more likely than men to suffer from diabetes, with 10% claiming to suffer from the condition, in comparison to 7% of males.<ref name=":13" />
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Diabetes]] [[Category:Indigenous health in Australia]]

revision.comment: Repair CS1 error(s), replaced: website=www. → website= (2)
revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=August 2017}} [[File:Stages of Childbirth.png|thumb|Normal Stages of Labor]] '''Emergency childbirth''' is the birth of an infant in places or situations other than what was planned. In most cases the location of childbirth is planned ahead of time and may be at home, a hospital, a medical facility or a birthing center. In other situations, the birth occurs on the way to these facilities. Oftentimes, no trained medical personnel are present, other times there may be police or other first responders. Emergency measures for delivery are indicated when childbirth is imminent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://medlineplus.gov/ency/imagepages/17001.htm|title=Emergency Childbirth: MedlinePlus Medical Encyclopedia Image|website=medlineplus.gov|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref>
==Background== Each year more than 250,000 women around the world die from complications due to [[childbirth]] or pregnancy, with [[Postpartum bleeding|bleeding]] and [[Hypertensive states of pregnancy|hypertension]] as the leading causes.<ref name=":9" /> Many of these deaths are preventable by emergency care, which include antibiotics, [[Uterotonic|drugs that stimulate contraction of the uterus]], [[Magnesium sulfate|anti-seizure drugs]], [[blood transfusion]], and delivery of baby with assistance (vacuum or forceps delivery) or [[Caesarean section|C-section]].<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Holmer|first=H|last2=Oyerinde|first2=K|last3=Meara|first3=Jg|last4=Gillies|first4=R|last5=Liljestrand|first5=J|last6=Hagander|first6=L|date=2015-01-01|title=The global met need for emergency obstetric care: a systematic review|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/1471-0528.13230/abstract|journal=BJOG: An International Journal of Obstetrics & Gynaecology|language=en|volume=122|issue=2|pages=183–189|doi=10.1111/1471-0528.13230|issn=1471-0528}}</ref>
In 2012, 1.36% of births took place outside of a hospital, and this number has been increasing over the last 30 years.<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=MacDorman|first=Marian F.|last2=Matthews|first2=T. J.|last3=Declercq|first3=Eugene|date=March 2014|title=Trends in out-of-hospital births in the United States, 1990-2012|journal=NCHS data brief|issue=144|pages=1–8|issn=1941-4927|pmid=24594003}}</ref> This is likely a combination of more home deliveries and deliveries at [[Birthing center|birth centers]], with 66% occurring at home and 29% in birthing centers.<ref name=":10" /> In a study of home deliveries in the US and Canada, about 12% of attempted home deliveries required urgent transport to hospital for more specialized care. Reasons for transfer include failure of labor to progress, maternal exhaustion or need for more pain medication, or maternal/fetal complications (see below).<ref name=":0" />
==Preparation== Pregnant women usually seek medical care throughout pregnancy and plan for the birth of a baby with a healthcare team. In an emergency childbirth situation, it is recommended to seek further education and make a plan.<ref name=":8" />
'''Early Preparation'''
Many childbirth education classes cover emergency birth procedures. Parents are trained to learn the signs of early labor or other indications that may require assistance. Caregivers can take a class on infant and child life support. Some recommend having a kit of emergency supplies in the home such as: clean towels, sheets, clean scissors, sterile gloves, sanitary pads, diapers, and instructions for infant-rescue breathing.<ref name=":3">{{cite web|url=https://emergency.cdc.gov/preparedness/pregnantfactsheet.asp|title=Information for Pregnant Women-What You Can Do|website=emergency.cdc.gov|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{cite web|url=https://www.health.harvard.edu/staying-healthy/emergencies-and-first-aid-childbirth|title=Emergencies and First Aid - Childbirth - Harvard Health|first=Harvard Health|last=Publications|publisher=|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref>
'''Late Preparation'''
Additional help may be found by calling 911 (in the United States) or an applicable number to get emergency medical services or nearby medical staff.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.uptodate.com/contents/precipitous-birth-not-occurring-on-a-labor-and-delivery-unit?source=search_result&search=emergency%20childbirth&selectedTitle=1~150|title=Precipitous birth not occurring on a labor and delivery unit|website=uptodate.com|access-date=2017-11-26}}</ref>
A vehicle driven safely toward medical care may be considered an acceptable option during the first stage of labor (dilation and effacement). During the second stage of labor (pushing and birth), a vehicle is usually stopped unless imminently arriving at a medical facility. If a vehicle is taken, additional occupants can support the mother and baby should assist in delivery. The mother and baby are kept warm throughout.<ref name=":11">{{Cite book|title=Emergency Obstetric Care|last=Blouse|first=Ann|last2=Gomez|first2=Patricia|publisher=United States Agency forvInternational Development|year=2003|url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/pnacy580.pdf|location=|pages=}}</ref>
If unable to reach a medical facility, a safe building with walls and a roof are sought that will provide protection from the environment. A warm and dry area with a bed is preferable.<ref name=":7">{{Cite book|title=Improvised Medicine: Providing Care in Extreme Environments, 2e|last=Iserson|first=Kenneth|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|year=2016|isbn=978-0-07-184762-9|location=|pages=Chapter 31}}</ref>
Supplies are collected for both the mother and the baby. Possible supplies may include blankets, pillows, towels, warm clean water, warm water bottles, soap, clean towels, baby clothes, sheets, sterile gloves, sanitary pads, diapers, identification tags for mother and baby, and instructions for infant-rescue breathing.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":7" /> A bed may be prepared for the baby with a basket or box lined with a blanket or sheets.<ref name=":7" /> Items are needed to clamp or tie the umbilical cord in two places. Shoestrings or strips of a sheet folded into narrow bands may be used.<ref name=":7" /> These items can be sterilized by boiling (20 minutes) or soaking in alcohol (up to 3 hours).<ref name=":7" /> Scissors or a knife are needed to cut the umbilical cord and may be sterilized with the same procedure.<ref name=":7" />
== Evaluation == A background obstetric history should be obtained: how many prior births has the patient had (if this is not her first birth, the patient's labor could be short), how many weeks along is she or what is her estimated date of delivery, any special concerns related to this pregnancy such as being told she has twins, being told she has a complication, or even if she has received regular prenatal care. Any other relevant medical history, allergies, drugs, recent signs of infections (fever) should be asked.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|url=http://accessmedicine.mhmedical.com/content.aspx?aid=1121506213|title=Tintinalli’s Emergency Medicine: A Comprehensive Study Guide|last=Frasure|first=Sarah Elisabeth|date=2016|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|editor-last=Tintinalli|editor-first=Judith E.|edition=8|location=New York, NY|editor-last2=Stapczynski|editor-first2=J. Stephan|editor-last3=Ma|editor-first3=O. John|editor-last4=Yealy|editor-first4=Donald M.|editor-last5=Meckler|editor-first5=Garth D.|editor-last6=Cline|editor-first6=David M.}}</ref>
'''Signs and Symptoms''' * ''Any gush of fluid?'' This would indicate that the [[rupture of membranes]] has occurred releasing amniotic fluid and that labor will probably begin soon if the patient is near term.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=http://accessmedicine.mhmedical.com.ucsf.idm.oclc.org/content.aspx?bookid=1057&sectionid=59789162|title=Williams Obstetrics, Twenty-Fourth Edition|last=Cunningham|first=F. Gary|date=2013|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-01}}</ref> * ''Any vaginal bleeding?'' Could indicate a [[bloody show]], a small amount of bloody discharge prior to labor, or if large amounts of bleeding occurred it could indicate potentially life-threatening complications.<ref name=":0" /> * ''How frequent are her contractions?'' One common recommendation is the patient may be in active labor if contractions are 5 minutes apart for one hour (if rupture of membranes has not occurred).<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2" /> * ''Does she feel the urge to push with her contractions?'' This is an indication delivery will occur soon.<ref name=":1" /> '''Physical Exam'''
If time permits and if trained: one should obtain vital signs to include maternal heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure, temperature, and oxygen rate.<ref name=":0" />
The patient should be draped with available blankets for privacy.
The patient's abdomen should be examined and felt for the presence of contractions,<ref name=":0" /> and the intensity, frequency, and length of contractions should be noted.<ref name=":2" />
With the patient's permission and privacy, an exam of the pelvic area should be performed; in general, one would: * Inspect to see if there is any presenting part of the baby. The baby's head will feel hard versus their buttocks will feel soft.<ref name=":1" /> * If the baby's head is presenting out of the vagina (crowning), then delivery will be happening soon and preparation should begin to deliver the baby<ref name=":1" /> * Trained physicians would conduct a manual cervical exam to determine the patient's [[cervical dilation]]. After the physical exam and if the patient is not crowning, the patient should be placed in the left lateral decubitus position (laying on her left side).<ref name=":0" />
== Delivery of term baby in normal position == '''First stage of labor:''' '''dilation and effacement of the cervix (before the baby comes out)'''
This stage of labor may last from 2 to 18 hours.<ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=CURRENT Diagnosis & Treatment: Obstetrics & Gynecology, 11e|last=Carol|first=Archie|publisher=The McGraw-Hill Companies|year=2013|isbn=978-0-07-163856-2|location=|pages=chapter 7}}</ref> Further care may be sought during this time. # Evaluation (above) is repeated, assessing for change in stage of labor.<ref name=":6">{{Cite book|title=Williams Obstetrics, Twenty-Fourth Edition|last=Cunningham|first=F|last2=et al.|publisher=McGraw-Hill Education|year=2014|isbn=978-0-07-179893-8|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref name=":5" /> # The mother is encouraged to walk or sit in a comfortable position.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":6" /><ref name=":5" /> '''Second stage: cervix is dilated (the baby is coming out)'''
This stage may last from 5 minutes to 3 hours.<ref name=":5" /> # Position. The mother is positioned in the [[lithotomy position]], lying on her back, with her feet above or at the same level as the hips. The [[perineum]] (the space between the vagina and anus) is positioned at the edge of a bed.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":5" /> # Wash. The perineum is cleaned with antiseptic solution or soap and water.<ref name=":7" /> Any assistants will wash hands with soap and water and put on sterile or clean gloves. # Pushing. Pushing is encouraged during contractions.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> # Head. The head of the baby is delivered. Delivery of the head is controlled to prevent rapid expulsion. One hand is placed on the perineum while the other applies gentle pressure to the baby’s head as it comes out.<ref name=":6" /> Soft pressure can be applied to the baby’s chin through the perineum to help expel the head. Rapid expulsion is still prevented with soft head pressure to reduce vaginal lacerations.<ref name=":6" /> # Cord check. A check is made to look for the presence of an umbilical cord ([[nuchal cord]]) around the baby’s neck.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> If it is present, an index finger is used to attempt to pull it over the baby’s head.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> If this cannot be done, the cord is clamped/tied in two places. Then the cord is carefully cut, avoiding injury to the baby or mother.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> # Front shoulder. The front shoulder is delivered. This is the shoulder on the mother's front side, towards her belly. The assistant holds the baby's head with two hands and may need to apply slight downward pressure (towards her anus) to help the front shoulder out. Firm pressure can injure the baby.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":6" /> If the shoulder gets stuck this is called shoulder dystocia. See procedure for relief of [[shoulder dystocia]] (below). # Back shoulder. The back shoulder is then delivered by providing slight upward pressure (away from her anus).<ref name=":6" /> # Catch baby. The baby usually comes out right away after both shoulders.<ref name=":6" /> The baby is caught noting that babies are slippery. The assistant holds the baby at the level of the vagina. # Cut cord. The [[umbilical cord]] is clamped and cut. The cord is clamped in two places about 6 cm to 8 cm from the baby.<ref name=":6" /> The clamps or ties are tight in order to stop the blood flow. The cord is cut between the two clamps or ties.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":5" /> Sterilized scissors or a sterilized knife is used.<ref name=":7" /> Another assistant may help with this. # Dry baby. The baby is dried, wrapped, and kept warm. Appropriate neonatal care is provided or the baby is placed to the mother's breast on her bare skin.<ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=Special Operations Forces Medical Handbook|last=Yevich|first=Steve|publisher=US Government|year=2001|isbn=|location=|pages=3–87}}</ref> An identification band may be placed on the baby.<ref name=":7" /> '''Third stage of labor: the delivery of the placenta'''
The baby is attached to the [[placenta]] by the umbilical cord. After the cord is cut, the placenta is usually still inside the mother. The placenta usually comes out in 2–10 minutes, but it may take up to 60 minutes.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":5" /> # Before the placenta is delivered there is a gush of blood as the cord gets longer.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":5" /> # The umbilical cord can be held taut, but must not be pulled with much force.<ref name=":6" /> # The placenta is delivered and is be inspected for completeness. The placenta should be stored in a bag for inspection by trained medical personnel.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":7" /> # The mother will need to have a trained physician inspect for vaginal lacerations that will need suture repair.
== Maternal complications == Complications of emergency childbirth include the complications that occur during normal childbirth. Maternal complications include perineal tearing during delivery, excessive bleeding ([[postpartum hemorrhage]]), retained products of conception in the uterus, hypertension, and seizures.
=== Vaginal Bleeding and Shock === In a pregnant woman, 40% of the circulating blood volume is in the uterus. This creates a large bleeding potential and high risk of [[Shock (circulatory)|hemorrhagic shock]] (low blood pressure from loss of circulating blood). For this reason, constant vigilance is important if any of the following occur:
- Vaginal bleeding early or late in pregnancy
- Severe abdominal pain
- Trauma (such as a fall or car accident) while pregnant
- Uncontrolled vaginal bleeding after the baby is delivered
- Inability to remove the entire placenta after the baby is delivered
==== First trimester bleeding ==== Causes of vaginal bleeding early in pregnancy include [[miscarriage]] (inevitable or incomplete abortion), embryo implantation and growth outside the uterus ([[ectopic pregnancy]]), and placenta attachment at the bottom of the uterus over the cervix ([[Placenta praevia|placenta previa]]), all of which can cause significant bleeding.
'''Bleeding after the first trimester and during delivery'''
Prior to and during delivery, bleeding can also occur from tears in the cervix, vagina, or perineum, sudden placental detachment ([[Placental abruption|abruptio placenta]]) and placental attachment over the cervix ([[placenta previa]]), and [[uterine rupture]].
'''Bleeding after delivery (postpartum hemorrhage)'''
After delivery of the baby, a uterus that is not contracting (atonic uterus), ruptured uterus, remaining parts of placenta or baby or infected remaining parts of placenta or baby can cause severe bleeding. Postpartum bleeding is usually managed preventatively by massaging the lower abdomen ([[fundal massage]]), which increases contraction of the uterus and stops bleeding. Additionally, steady traction is applied to the cord to prevent trauma, cord avulsion (tearing of the umbilical cord), uterine inversion, and retained placental products, all of which can increase blood loss and/or the risk of infection.
Postpartum hemorrhage is defined by loss of more than 500 mL blood within 24 hours after delivery. It is difficult to predict with few known risk factors and occurs in 3% of women, leading to ~150,000 annual deaths worldwide.<ref name=":7" /> Once uncontrolled bleeding occurs, management can be manual (fundal massage from the outside, packing the uterus, tamponading bleeding from the inside with balloon or condom catheter), and pharmacological (with [[Oxytocin (medication)|oxytocin]], [[ergotamine]], [[misoprostol]]). Alongside these treatments, shock should be addressed with IV fluids or blood transfusions as discussed below.
'''Severe blood loss leading to shock'''
In shock, you may see cold clammy skin, pale skin (especially around eyes, mouth, and hands), sweating, anxiousness, and loss of consciousness. You may note a fast heartbeat (110 beats per minute or more), low blood pressure (90mmHg systolic or less), and decreased urine output.
The woman should be laid on her left side, with legs and buttocks elevated to encourage blood flow back to the heart with gravity. If available, IV fluids (Ringer’s lactate or normal saline) should be started with monitoring of her heart rate, blood pressure, and appearance. If available, two large bore IV catheters (16-gauge or largest available) should be used to rapidly infuse 1L in 15–20 minutes, with a goal of giving 2L in the first hour. If unable to start an IV and the woman is able to drink and is conscious with no recent convulsions, give 300-500 mL of fluid by mouth. If the woman is unable to drink, is unconscious, or has recently had convulsions, fluid can be given rectally with an enema bag or can. Fill the enema with 500mL IV fluid, clamp the end of the tube and insert 10 cm (3-4inches) into the rectum. If filling an enema, run water slowly or cramping can occur, pushing the water back out.
=== Convulsions (Seizures) === Convulsions (Seizures) in pregnancy can be caused by pregnancy specific causes of seizures such as [[eclampsia]] and by normal causes of seizures such as [[epilepsy]]. Warning signs that may lead to convulsions include [[Pre-eclampsia|pre-eclamsia]], which is a condition that pregnant women can get after 20 weeks of pregnancy that is characterized by new-onset high blood pressure, headaches, blurry vision, [[Pulmonary edema|trouble breathing from fluid in lungs]], [[Proteinuria|protein in urine from kidney failure]], and elevated liver enzymes from liver dysfunction, and possibly coagulation defects from platelet dysfunction.
If a pregnant woman begins to have convulsions, additional help and assistance should be sought. One should not restrain the patient, but lie her down on her left side and check the airway (mouth, nose, throat). Turning the patient on her side decreases risk of [[Pulmonary aspiration|breathing in vomit and spit]]. If available, magnesium sulfate is the preferred treatment for seizures in pregnant women, starting with a dose of 4 mg IV over 5 minutes.<ref name=":11" /> A sensation of warmth during infusion is normal, however, there is also a risk of stopping breathing with magnesium sulfate use, which would indicate the dosage is too high. If this occurs, calcium gluconate can be used to reverse the effects (1g IV over 10 minutes, often in solution).<ref name=":11" /> In general, make sure the breathing rate is at least 16 breaths per minute and the knee jerk reflex is still intact before giving more magnesium sulfate. If magnesium sulfate is unavailable, diazepam can be used to treat convulsions in pregnancy. The first dose, the loading dose, should be 10 mg of diazepam IV given over 2 minutes.<ref name=QuickRef>{{Cite web|url=http://pdf.usaid.gov/pdf_docs/pnacy580.pdf|title=Emergency Obstetric Care: Quick Reference Guide for Frontline Providers|last=United States Agency for International Development|first=Editors: Ann Blouse and Patricia Gomez|date=Sep 2003|website=USAID|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> After this, the loading dose can be repeated. The maintenance dose is 40 mg of diazepam in 500mL IV fluids. The amount of diazepam used should never be more than 100 mg in 24 hours and it should be dosed in order to keep the woman awake, rousable, and breathing rate above 16 breaths per minute<ref name=QuickRef/>
== Fetal care == Almost 10% of newborns require some resuscitative care. Common complications of childbirth that relate to the baby include [[Breech birth|breech presentation]], [[shoulder dystocia]], [[Chorioamnionitis|infection]], and umbilical cord wrapped around the baby's neck ([[nuchal cord]]).
'''Evaluation'''
The newborn is evaluated at 1 and 5 minutes after birth using the [[Apgar score|Apgar]] score, which assigns points based on appearance (color), pulse, grimace (cry), activity (muscle tone), and respiration (breathing effort), with each component scored from 0 to 2. Scores below 7 generally require further care (see resuscitation below).
'''Routine care'''
After initial evaluation, babies with good Apgar scores are dried and rubbed, any obstruction of breathing is cleared, and they are warmed either with skin-to-skin contact with the mother or under a heat source.
=== Complications === With United States home births as an estimate, neonatal complications are common, with cord wrapped around the head 12-37% of the time ([[nuchal cord]]), insufficient oxygenation ([[Perinatal asphyxia|birth asphyxia]]) 9% of the time, pulselessness 6% of the time, and breech presentation 3% of the time<ref>"Obstetrics/Gynecology." ''''Improvised Medicine: Providing Care in Extreme Environments, 2e'''' Ed. Kenneth V. Iserson. New York, NY: McGraw-Hill, , <nowiki>http://accessmedicine.mhmedical.com.ucsf.idm.oclc.org/content.aspx?bookid=1728&sectionid=115697898</nowiki>.</ref>
'''Breech Presentation''' [[File:Frank breech.jpg|thumb| Frank Breech Presentation (buttocks first) is the most common type of breech presentation ]]
Normally, the head is the first part of the body to present out of the birth canal. However, other parts such as the buttocks or feet can present first, which is referred to as [[Breech birth|breech presentation]]. Risk for breech presentation may increase with multiple pregnancies (more than one baby), when there is too little or too much fluid in the uterus, or if the uterus is abnormally shaped.<ref name=":6" /> Babies in breech presentation can be delivered vaginally depending on the experience of the provider and if the fetus meets specific low risk criteria, however C-section is recommended if available.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.acog.org/Resources-And-Publications/Committee-Opinions/Committee-on-Obstetric-Practice/Mode-of-Term-Singleton-Breech-Delivery|title=Mode of Term Singleton Breech Delivery - ACOG|website=acog.org|access-date=2017-12-12}}</ref> Ideally, vaginal breech delivery should not be performed without the availability of nearby emergency C-section capabilities and extensive efforts should be made to bring a woman in labor with breech presentation to a hospital. There are many variations of breech presentations and multiple ways the baby can get stuck during delivery. If a breech delivery is occurring, the provider will guide the hips out by giving light, downward traction holding the pelvis until the scapula is present. Then at the level of the armpits, each shoulder is delivered by rotating the baby as required, then subsequently rotating 180 degrees to deliver the other shoulder. The head is delivered with careful attention to the baby's arms. The arms will be delivered downwards through the vulva and may have to be gently held downwards by the provider's fingers.<ref name=":2" />
'''Pre-term labor'''
Incidence of preterm delivery is approximately 12%, and preterm births are a significant contributing cause of unplanned emergency delivery.<ref name=":0" /> Pre-term labor is defined as occurring before 37 weeks, and risks for pre-term labor include pregnancy with multiple fetuses, prior history of premature labor, structural abnormalities of the cervix or uterus, urinary tract, vaginal, or sexually transmitted infections, high blood pressure, drug use, diabetes, blood disorders, or pregnancy occurring less than 6 months after a prior pregnancy.<ref name=":2" /> The same principles of term emergency delivery apply to emergency delivery for a [[Preterm birth|preterm fetus]], though the baby will be at higher risk of other problems such as [[low birth weight]], trouble breathing, and infections. The newborn will need additional medical care and monitoring after delivery and should be taken to a hospital providing neonatal care, which may include antibiotics and breathing treatments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/gynecology-and-obstetrics/abnormalities-and-complications-of-labor-and-delivery/preterm-labor|title=Preterm Labor - Gynecology and Obstetrics - Merck Manuals Professional Edition|work=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}}</ref>
'''Shoulder dystocia'''
In [[shoulder dystocia]], the shoulder is trapped after the head is delivered, preventing delivery of the rest of the baby. The major risk factor (other than prior history of shoulder dystocia) is the baby being too large ([[Large for gestational age|macrosomia]]), which can result from the mother being obese or gaining too much weight, diabetes, and the pregnancy lasting too long ([[Postterm pregnancy|post-term pregnancy]]).<ref name=":6" /> Shoulder dystocia can lead to further fetal complications such as nerve compression and injury at the shoulder ([[Brachial plexus injury|brachial plexus]]), fracture of the collarbone, and low oxygen for the fetus (whether due to compression of the umbilical cord or due to inability of the baby to breathe). Shoulder dystocia is often signaled by retreat of the head between contractions when it has already been delivered ("turtle sign"). Treatment includes the [[McRoberts maneuver]], where the mother flexes her thighs up to her stomach with her knees wide apart as pressure is applied on her lower abdomen, and [[Woods' screw maneuver]], where the deliverer inserts a hand into the vagina to rotate the fetus.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.merckmanuals.com/professional/gynecology-and-obstetrics/abnormalities-and-complications-of-labor-and-delivery/fetal-dystocia|title=Fetal Dystocia - Gynecology and Obstetrics - Merck Manuals Professional Edition|work=Merck Manuals Professional Edition|access-date=2017-12-12|language=en-US}}</ref> If all maneuvers fail, then C-section would be indicated.
'''Prolapsed Cord''' [[File:Cord.prolaps.jpg|thumb|Umbilical Cord Prolapse]]
A prolapsed cord refers to an umbilical cord that is delivered from the uterus while the baby is still in the uterus and is life-threatening to the baby. Cord prolapse creates a risk of decreased blood flow (and oxygen flow) to the baby as delivery will cause cord compression. However, if the cord delivers before the baby, the cord should not be placed back into the uterus through the cervix since this increases risk of infection.<ref>Kahana B, Sheiner E, Levy A et al.: Umbilical cord prolapse and perinatal outcomes. ''Int J Gynaecol Obstet'' 84: 127, 2004. [PubMed: 14871514]</ref> Emergent obstetric care for C-section would be indicated, and in the meantime, one should elevate the foot of the bed if possible to attempt to keep the baby above the level of the cord.<ref name=":0" /> If no specialized care is available, one may attempt to reduce pressure of the cord manually and continue delivery, but also being prepared to clamp and cut the cord if needed.
'''Nuchal Cord'''
After the baby crowns, the umbilical cord may be found to be wrapped around the neck or body of the baby, which is known as nuchal cord. This is common, occurring in up to 37% of term pregnancies, and most do not cause any long-term problems.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Peesay|first=Morarji|date=2012-08-28|title=Cord around the neck syndrome|journal=BMC Pregnancy and Childbirth|volume=12|issue=Suppl 1|pages=A6|doi=10.1186/1471-2393-12-S1-A6|issn=1471-2393|pmc=3428673}}</ref> This wrapped cord should be slipped over the head so it is not pulled during delivery. If the wrap is not removed, it can choke the baby or can cause the placenta to detach suddenly which can cause severe maternal bleeding and loss of blood and oxygen to the baby. The cord may also be wrapped around a limb in breech presentation, and should similarly be reduced in these cases.
'''Resuscitation'''
If the baby is not doing well on its own, further care may be necessary. Resuscitation typically starts with warming, drying, and stimulating the newborn. If breathing difficulty is noted, the airway is opened and cleared with suction and oxygen is monitored; if necessary, one may consider using a positive airway pressure ventilator (which gives oxygen while keeping the airway open) or intubation. If the heart rate is below 60 beats per minute, CPR is started at 3:1 compression to ventilation ratio, with compressions given at the lower breastbone. If this fails to revive the newborn, epinephrine will be given.<ref name=":0" />
Resuscitation is not indicated for newborns below 22 weeks of gestation and weighing below 400 grams. Resuscitation may also be discontinued if the baby's heart does not start after 10–15 minutes of full resuscitation (including breathing treatments, medications, and CPR).
==In culture== The reports of emergency childbirth are typically of general interest. A mobile app was developed in Ethiopia that guides users through the procedures of assisting with an emergency birth.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://qz.com/548047/a-mobile-app-could-make-childbirth-safer-in-ethiopia-one-of-the-deadliest-countries-to-have-a-baby/|title=A mobile app could make childbirth safer in Ethiopia, one of the deadliest countries to have a baby|first=Lily|last=Kuo|publisher=|accessdate=3 August 2017}}</ref>
==References== [[File:Blue_question_mark_icon.svg|12px|]] <small>[[Wikipedia:Research help|Using Wikipedia for Research]]</small> {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{about|the fruit}} {{Speciesbox |name = Gấc |image = Qua_Gac.JPG |image_caption = Exterior and cross-sectional interior of gac |genus = Momordica |species = cochinchinensis |authority = [[João de Loureiro|(Lour.)]] [[Kurt Sprengel|Spreng.]] }} '''Gấc''' (''[[Momordica cochinchinensis]]'') is a type of perennial vine grown throughout [[Southeast Asia]]n countries and [[Northeastern Australia]]. Gấc is notable for its orange-reddish color resulting from its rich content of [[beta-carotene]] and [[lycopene]]. == Etymology == As gac was originally discovered in Vietnam, it is commonly called by its [[Vietnamese language|Vietnamese]] name (gấc, {{IPA-vi|ɣək˦˥|pron}}). The fruit may also be called "quả gấc" as "quả" means "fruit" in English, and has various common names.{{Cite web|url=https://npgsweb.ars-grin.gov/gringlobal/taxonomydetail.aspx?id=24521|title=Taxon: ''Momordica cochinchinensis'' (Lour.) Spreng. U.S. National Plant Germplasm System.|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-11-26}} By its [[binomial nomenclature|scientific name]], ''cochinchinensis'' originates from the name for southern Vietnam during the period of [[French colonial empire|French colonization]], [[Cochinchina]]. [[Momordica]] is a genus belonging to the [[Cucurbitaceae]] family, including [[Momordica charantia|bitter cucumber]]. == History == Around 200 years ago, the [[Portuguese people|Portuguese]] priest, J. Lourciso, visited Vietnam and discovered the plant.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} He gave it the name ''Muricia cochinchinensis'' in the book ''Flora Cochinchinesis'' published in 1790.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} Later, Sprengel found that the plant belonged to the Linnean genus ''Momordica'' and changed its name in 1826.{{Cite journal|last=Vuong|first=Le|date=2000|title=Underutilized β-Carotene–Rich Crops of Vietnam|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/233584507_Underutilized_b-Carotene-Rich_Crops_of_Vietnam|journal=Food & Nutrition Bulletin|volume=21|pages=173–181|doi=10.1177/156482650002100211|via=}} ==Characteristics== Gac grows as [[Dioecy|dioecious]] vines, meaning its male and female flowers are on separate plants, producing flowers typically {{convert|5-10|cm|in}} in length. Its vines can extend to {{convert|20|m|ft}} long, and its flowers blooms once a year, single or in bundle, around 2–3 months after the vines are planted. In one season, a plant can produce from 30 to 60 fruits.{{Cite journal|last=Osman|first=Mohamad|last2=Sulaiman|first2=Zulkefly|last3=Saleh|first3=Ghizan|last4=Shahril Ab Rahman|first4=Mohd.|last5=Mohd. Zainuddin|first5=Zulkifli|last6=Abu Sin|first6=Maizura|last7=Arina ab halim|first7=Anna|last8=Hamidon|first8=Azimah|vauthors=|date=|year=2017|title=Gac fruit, a plant genetic resource with high potential.|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/323846407_Gac_fruit_a_plant_genetic_resource_with_high_potential|journal=Transactions of Persatuan Genetik Malaysia|volume=7|pages=|via=}} Approximately five months after flowering, the ripe bright-red fruits can be harvested, usually over September to December annually.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} === Fruit === [[File:Gac Fruit.jpg|thumb|Gac fruit, [[Philippines]]]] [[File:Momordica sp Blanco2.380.png|thumb|150px|Gac fruit]] Typically, gac fruits are round or oblong, about {{convert|13|cm|in}} in length and {{convert|10|cm|in}} in diameter, covered with small spines on the [[exocarp]]. Upon ripening, gac gradually changes colors, from green to yellow, orange and finally red when it can be harvested. At this time, the fruit is hard, but turns soft quickly, creating a challenge for storage and transportation. Gac fruit has a mild taste and dense flesh ([[mesocarp]]). The inside of a gac fruit comprises two parts: fruit (yellow) and seed membrane (red color). Larger fruits have a higher percentage of edible [[aril]] than smaller fruits.{{Cite journal|last=Parks|first=Sophie|last2=Murray|first2=Carly|last3=Gale|first3=David|last4=AL-Khawaldeh|first4=B|last5=Spohr|first5=Lorraine|date=|year=2013|title=Propagation and production of Gac (Momordica Cochinchinensis Spreng.), A greenhouse case study.|url=https://www.researchgate.net/publication/259431185_Propagation_and_production_of_Gac_Momordica_Cochinchinensis_Spreng_A_greenhouse_case_study|journal=Experimental Agriculture|volume=49|issue=2|pages=|doi=10.1017/S0014479712001081|via=}} ==Breeding and cultivation== As gac plant is [[Dioecy|dioecious]], both male and female plants are needed; hence, farmers must have at least one corresponding male plant growing in or around the gardens for the fruit-bearing female plants to be pollinated. In order to breed, gac can change sex, and may change from one season to the next.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} When grown from seed, the ratio of male to female plants is unpredictable. [[Pollination]] may be facilitated by insects, but hand pollination results in a higher fruit yield. New plants can also be generated from root tubers as a more reliable method to yield fruits, because [[germination]] by seeds can be difficult due to several environmental factors such as [[dormancy]] or plant age.{{citation needed|date=November 2018}} An alternative method is to [[grafting|graft]] female material onto the main shoot of a male plant.{{Cite web|url=https://gacfruit.weebly.com/propagation-and-cultivation-of-gac-plant.html|title=Propagation and cultivation of Gac plant|website=Gac Research
University of Newcastle, Australia|language=en|access-date=2018-11-26}} For maximum insect-aided pollination, the recommended ratio is about 1 male for every 10 female plants. If propagating from vines, farmers make diagonal cut (around {{convert|15-20|cm|in}} long and {{convert|3-6|mm|in}} wide), then root the tubers in water or well-aerated, moist potting media before planting. Apart from Southeast Asian countries where the fruits are native, gac can be grown in [[Subtropics|sub-tropical]] climate regions. Cool temperatures inhibit growth. == Uses == [[File:Xôi gấc.JPG|thumb|Glutinous rice made with extract of ripe fruits of ''Momordica cochinchinensis'', Vietnamese style]] Gac has been commonly used in its native countries, mainly as food and [[traditional medicine]]. Its use as medicine dated back to over 1200 years ago in China and Vietnam{{Cite web|url=https://research.jcu.edu.au/bmdt/news-and-updates/researchers-use-nature-to-fight-cancer|title=Researchers use nature to fight cancer|website=Research@JCU|language=en-GB|access-date=2018-11-26}} Gac seeds, known as ''[[wikt:mù|mù]] [[wikt:biē|biē]] [[wikt:zǐ|zǐ]]'' (meaning 'wooden turtle seed'), are used for a variety of internal and [[topical medication|topical]] purposes in traditional medicine.{{Cite journal|last=Chuyen|first=Hoang|last2=Nguyen|first2=Minh|last3=Roach|first3=Paul|last4=Golding|first4=John|last5=Parks|first5=Sophie|date=Spring 2015|title=Gac fruit (''Momordica cochinchinensis'' Soreng,): a rich source of bioactive compounds and its potential health benefits|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/ijfs.12721/abstract|journal=Food Science and Technology|volume=50|pages=567–577|doi=10.1111/ijfs.12721}} The [[aril]] surrounding gac seeds when the fruits are ripe is cooked with sticky rice to make “[[Xôi]] Gấc”, a traditional Vietnamese dish in red color served at weddings and New Year celebrations. In addition, the immature green fruit is also used as a vegetable in India.{{Cite journal|last=Tran|first=Xuan T.|last2=Parks|first2=Sophie E.|last3=Roach|first3=Paul D.|last4=Golding|first4=John B.|last5=Nguyen|first5=Minh H.|date=2015-10-06|title=Effects of maturity on physicochemical properties of Gac fruit (Momordica cochinchinensis Spreng.)|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4779482/|journal=Food Science & Nutrition|volume=4|issue=2|pages=305–314|doi=10.1002/fsn3.291|issn=2048-7177|pmc=4779482|pmid=27004120|via=}} The spiny skin is removed and the fruits are sliced and cooked sometimes with potato or bottle gourd. In Sri Lanka, gac is used in curry, and in Thailand, gac is served with ice cream.{{Cite news|url=https://www.rmit.edu.vn/news/rmit-researcher-uncovers-exceptional-health-benefits-gac-fruit|title=RMIT researcher uncovers the exceptional health benefits of gấc fruit|work=RMIT University Vietnam|access-date=2018-11-26|language=en}} Due to the high contents of [[Beta-Carotene|beta-carotene]] and [[lycopene]], [[extract]]s from gac aril are used to manufacture [[dietary supplement]]s in soft [[capsule (pharmacy)|capsules]] or included in a juice blend.{{cite web|author1=Lawrence Goodman|title=The Next Big Fruit Juice?|url=http://www.brownalumnimagazine.com/content/view/3960/32/|publisher=Brown Alumni Magazine|accessdate=12 August 2017|date=August 2015}} Vietnamese children fed a rice dish containing gấc had higher blood levels of beta-carotene than those not fed gac.{{cite journal |vauthors=Vuong LT, Dueker SR, Murphy SP | title = Plasma β-Carotene and Retinol Concentrations of Children Increase After a 30-d Supplementation with the Fruit ''Momordica cochinchinensis'' (Gac) | journal = Am. J. Clin. Nutr. | year = 2002 | volume = 75 | issue = 5 | pages = 872–9 | pmid = 11976161 | url = http://ajcn.nutrition.org/content/75/5/872.long | accessdate = 5 January 2013 }} ==Nutrients and phytochemicals== Various studies show gac contains large amounts of beta-carotene and lycopene.{{Cite journal|last=Mai|first=H. C.|last2=Truong|first2=V|last3=Debaste|first3=F|vauthors=|date=2014|title=Carotenoids concentration of gac (''Momordica cochinchinensis'' Spreng.) fruit oil using cross-flow filtration technology|url=|journal=Journal of Food Science|volume=79|issue=11|pages=E2222–31|doi=10.1111/1750-3841.12661|pmid=25367308|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Maoka|first=T|last2=Yamano|first2=Y|last3=Wada|first3=A|last4=Etho|first4=T|last5=Terada|first5=Y|last6=Tokuda|first6=H|last7=Nishino|first7=H|date=|year=2015|title=Oxidative metabolites of lycopene and γ-carotene in gac (''Momordica cochinchinensis'')|url=|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry|volume=63|issue=5|pages=1622–30|doi=10.1021/jf505008d|pmid=25633727|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Wimalasiri|first=Dilani|last2=Brkljača|first2=Robert|last3=Piva|first3=Terrence J.|last4=Urban|first4=Sylvia|last5=Huynh|first5=Tien|date=2017|title=Comparative analysis of carotenoid content in ''Momordica cochinchinensis'' (Cucurbitaceae) collected from Australia, Thailand and Vietnam|journal=Journal of Food Science and Technology|volume=54|issue=9|pages=2814–2824|doi=10.1007/s13197-017-2719-0|issn=0022-1155|pmc=5583111|pmid=28928521|via=}} Both aril and seeds are rich in [[Monounsaturated fat|monounsaturated]] and [[Polyunsaturated fat|polyunsaturated]] [[fatty acid]]s.{{Cite journal|last=Ishida|first=Betty|last2=Turner|first2=Charlotta|last3=Chapman|first3=Mary|last4=A McKeon|first4=Thomas|date=2004|title=Fatty acid and carotenoid composition of gac (''Momordica cochinchinensis'' Spreng) Fruit|url=|journal=Journal of Agricultural and Food Chemistry|volume=52|pages=274–9|doi=10.1021/jf030616i|pmid=14733508}} Seventy percent of total fatty acids in the aril are unsaturated, and 50% of these are polyunsaturated. Unusual for fruits, gac has a high concentration of linoleic acid ([[Omega-6 fatty acid|omega-6]]) and [[omega-3 fatty acid]]s. The presence of fat in the gac fruit aril may enhance absorption of carotenoids and other fat-soluble nutrients, as indicated in preliminary research to increase their [[bioavailability]] compared to carrots and tomatoes.{{Cite journal|last=Müller-Maatsch|first=Judith|last2=Sprenger|first2=Jasmin|last3=Hempel|first3=Judith|last4=Kreiser|first4=Florence|last5=Carle|first5=Reinhold|last6=Schweiggert|first6=Ralf M.|date=2017-09-01|title=Carotenoids from gac fruit aril (''Momordica cochinchinensis'' [Lour.] Spreng.) are more bioaccessible than those from carrot root and tomato fruit|url=https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0963996916305257|journal=Food Research International|language=en|volume=99|pages=928–935|doi=10.1016/j.foodres.2016.10.053|issn=0963-9969|pmid=28847429}} Despite the high levels of fatty acids and other nutrients in gac seeds, they are normally discarded, becoming waste products. ==References== {{Reflist|30em}} ==External links== *{{Commons category inline|Momordica cochinchinensis}} {{Taxonbar|from=Q311079}} [[Category:Dietary supplements]] [[Category:Dioecious plants]] [[Category:Edible fruits]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Asia]] [[Category:Medicinal plants of Oceania]] [[Category:Momordica]] [[Category:Plants used in traditional Chinese medicine]]

{{Infobox dam | name = Halali | name_official = | image = | image_size = | image_caption = | image_alt = | location_map = India | location_map_size = | location_map_caption = | coordinates = {{coord|23.49|N|77.51|E|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | country = India | location = [[Raisen district]] | status = | construction_began = | opening = 1973 | demolished = | cost = | owner = | dam_type = | dam_height = | dam_height_thalweg = | dam_height_foundation= | dam_length = | dam_width_crest = | dam_width_base = | dam_volume = 227 million m<sup>3</sup> | dam_elevation_crest = | dam_crosses = | spillway_count = | spillway_type = | spillway_capacity = | res_name = | res_capacity_total = | res_capacity_active = | res_capacity_inactive= | res_catchment = | res_surface = 2528 ha (full res. level); 2590 (dead res. level) | res_elevation = 458 m above MSL | res_max_depth = | res_max_length = | res_max_width = | res_tidal_range = | plant_operator = | plant_commission = | plant_decommission = | plant_type = | plant_turbines = | plant_capacity = | plant_annual_gen = | website = | extra = Source: [[Food and Agriculture Organization|FAO]]<ref name="fao_fisheries_mp">{{cite web | url = http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/003/V5930E/V5930E09.htm | title = Reservoir Fisheries of India: Madhya Pradesh | publisher = Fisheries and Aquaculture Department, Food and Agriculture Organization of the United Nations | accessdate = 2011-11-03 }}</ref> }} The '''Halali reservoir''' is a [[reservoir]] in the [[Raisen district]] of [[Madhya Pradesh]], India. It is built on the Halali River, and lies 40 km away from the state capital [[Bhopal]].<ref>{{cite web | url = http://wldb.ilec.or.jp/data/ilec/wlc12/B%20-%20Water%20Quality/B-26.pdf | title = Water Quality Monitoring of Halali Reservoir with Reference to Cage Aquaculture as a Modern Tool for Obtaining Enhanced Fish Production | author = Praveen Tamot, Rajeev Mishra and Somdutt | publisher = International Lake Environment Committee Foundation | year = 2008 | accessdate = 2011-11-03 }}</ref>
The major fish species found in the reservoir include [[catla]], [[rohu]], [[mrigal]], [[wallago attu]], [[mystus]] and [[chitala]].<ref name="fao_fisheries_mp"/>
== Halali River ==
The Halali River is a tributary of the [[Betwa River]]. It was formerly known as Thal River. In the 18th century, [[Dost Mohammad Khan, Nawab of Bhopal|Dost Mohammad Khan]]'s forces killed a rival [[Rajput]] force near Jagdishpur (later renamed to [[Islamnagar, Bhopal|Islamnagar]]) on the bank of the river. The river was renamed to "[[Halal]]i river" (the river of slaughter), because it appeared red with the blood of the victims.<ref name="Shaharyar_Begums_2000">{{cite book | title = The Begums of Bhopal | author = Shaharyar M. Khan | edition = illustrated | publisher = I.B.Tauris | year = 2000 | isbn = 978-1-86064-528-0 | pages = 1–29 }}</ref> Another name for the river is Banganga.
The Halali reservoir was commissioned in 1973.<ref name="fao_fisheries_mp"/>
