{{About|the Emergency Medical Services organization|the holocaust rescue organization|Vaad Hatzalah}}
[[Image:Hatzalah.jpg|right|220px|thumb|Hatzalah ambulance in [[Crown Heights, Brooklyn|Crown Heights]], [[Brooklyn]], [[New York City]]]]
'''Hatzalah''' ("rescue" or "relief" in {{lang-he-n|הצלה}}) is a volunteer [[Emergency medical services|emergency medical service]] (EMS) organization serving mostly [[Jew]]ish communities around the world. Most local branches operate independently of each other, but use the common name. The Hebrew spelling of the name is always the same, but there are many variations in transliteration, such as Hatzolah, Hatzoloh and Hatzola.<ref name="Affiliates">{{cite web |title=Affiliates|url=http://www.hatzalah.org/affiliates.php}}</ref> It is also often called Chevra Hatzalah, which loosely translates as "Company of Rescuers" or "Group of Rescuers."
==History==
The original Hatzalah EMS was founded in [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn]], [[New York (state)|New York]], USA by Rabbi Hershel Weber in the late 1960s,<ref name="Willie">{{cite web |url=http://www.hatzolahw.org/ourmission.html |title=Williamsburg Services}}</ref> to improve rapid emergency medical response in the community, and to mitigate cultural concerns of a [[Yiddish]]-speaking, religious [[Hasidic]] community. The idea spread to other [[Orthodox Judaism|Orthodox Jewish]] neighborhoods in the [[New York metropolitan area|New York City area]], and eventually to other regions, countries, and continents. Hatzalah is believed to be the largest volunteer ambulance service in the world.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://apps.fcc.gov/ecfs/document/view%3Bjsessionid%3Dw4xxP4MQs1mhdJ2J5PJxv1b4CNnJyfYlys71Bcp2GmjCtvSb0TY0!-1969853125!-1221852939%3Fid%3D7021905105 |title=Chevrah Hatzalah |work=Request to FCC regarding access to Blocked Telephone Numbers |author=E C Cooper |date=30 March 2012 |publisher=fcc.gov |format=PDF |accessdate=27 December 2014 }} "Hatzalah is the only volunteer ambulance service licensed to serve the entire City of New York, and it is believed to be the largest volunteer ambulance service in the nation."</ref><ref>The [[Edhi Foundation]] with more than 500 ambulances has held the [[Guinness World Records|Guinness record]] for world's "largest volunteer ambulance organization" since 1997. *{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hLYzvUvPL3MC&pg=PA237#v=onepage&q=%22largest%20volunteer%20ambulance%22&f=false |title=Guinness World Records 2010 |editor=Craig Glenday |publisher=Bantam Books |year=2010 |isbn=9780553593372 |page=237}}</ref> Chevra Hatzalah in New York has more than a thousand volunteer EMTs and paramedics who answer more than 70,000 calls each year with private vehicles and a fleet of more than 90 ambulances.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bphatzolah.org/about.html|title=Boro Park Hatzolah Volunteer Ambulance|publisher=|accessdate=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161204035211/http://www.bphatzolah.org/about.html|archive-date=2016-12-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref>
Hatzalah organizations now function in [[Argentina]], [[Australia]], [[Austria]], [[Belgium]], [[Brazil]], [[Canada]], [[Israel]], [[Mexico]], [[Panama]],<ref name=h-panama>{{cite web|title=Hatzalah Panama - Home|url=http://uhpma.org/|publisher=Hatzalah Panama|accessdate=15 November 2013}}</ref> [[Russia]],<ref name=Russia>{{cite web | title = Emergency Response Service for Jews in Russia's Capital | url = http://www.fjc.ru/news/newsArticle.asp?AID=235422 | year = 2004 | accessdate = 2006-12-26 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070226225259/http://www.fjc.ru/news/newsArticle.asp?AID=235422 | archivedate = 2007-02-26 | df = }}</ref> [[South Africa]], [[Switzerland]], [[United Kingdom]],<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/2666123.stm|title=Jewish health service offers local care| work=BBC News | date=2003-01-19 | accessdate=2010-01-05| first=Caroline| last=Ryan}}</ref> [[Ukraine]], and in 10 states in the [[United States|US]]: [[California]], [[Connecticut]], [[Florida]], [[Illinois]], [[Maryland]], [[New Jersey]], [[New York (state)|New York]], [[Pennsylvania]] and [[Michigan]]. Hatzalah branches are currently being organized in other states as well.
In Israel, there are two Hatzalah organizations operating on the national level, [[United Hatzalah|Ichud Hatzalah]] ({{lang-he|איחוד הצלה}}), Hebrew for, "[[United Hatzalah]]", and Tzevet Hatzalah (Hebrew: צוות הצלה). While [[United Hatzalah]] is unarguably the larger of the two organizations, their volunteers are limited to direct response on scene care, versus Tzevet Hatzalah volunteers which are additionally licensed and authorized to provide emergency transport utilizing [[Magen David Adom]] ambulances.
==Operations== Hatzalah uses a [[fly-car]] system, where members are assigned [[Ad hoc|ad-hoc]] to respond to the emergency. The dispatcher requests any units for a particular emergency location. Members who think they will have best response times respond via [[Walkie-talkie|handheld radios]], and the dispatcher confirms the appropriate members. Two members will typically respond directly to the call in their private vehicles. A third member retrieves an [[ambulance]] from a base location.<ref name="NYC Ops"/>
Each directly dispatched Hatzolah volunteer has a full medical technician "jump kit," in their car, with oxygen, trauma, and appropriate pharmaceutical supplies. Paramedic (EMT-P) members carry more extensive equipment and supplies, including [[EKG]], [[Intravenous therapy|IV]], injection, intubation, and more pharmaceuticals. Each volunteer is called a ''unit'' (as in, a crew of one), and is assigned a unit number that starts with a neighborhood code, followed by a [[serial number]] for that neighborhood (e.g., "Q-381" means "Queens unit number 381"<ref name="Madrich">{{cite book |title=Madrich L'Chevra Hatzalah |last=Handler |first=Mechel |author2=Rabbi Dovid Weinberger |publisher=Feldheim}}</ref>). Ambulances also have unit numbers in the same format, with the first few numbers for each neighborhood reserved for the ambulance numbers.<ref name="NYC Ops"/> Some neighborhoods have begun to assign 3-digit unit numbers to their ambulances, using numbers out of the range assigned to human member units (e.g. 900-numbers).
In some areas there may be periods where coverage is not strong enough, for example on a summer weekend. When this happens, coordinators may assign an on-call rotation. The rotation may still respond from their houses, or they may stay at the garage through their shift. In such periods, Hatzalah functions closer to a typical EMS crew setup, though the dispatchers may still seek non-on-call members to respond, and there will still often be a non-ambulance responder as first dispatched, even if that responder starts from the base.<ref name="Madrich"/>
In [[Israel]], [[United Hatzalah]] relies upon mobile phone technologies which include an SOS [[Mobile app|app]] and a special emergency phone number, 1221, with messages to news organizations distributed by [[WhatsApp]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Wootliff|first1=Raoul|title=After blogs and Facebook, military censor sets sights on WhatsApp|url=http://www.timesofisrael.com/after-blogs-and-facebook-military-censor-sets-sights-on-whatsapp/|accessdate=17 February 2016|work=[[The Times of Israel]]|date=17 February 2016}}</ref>
===Response times=== Hatzalah's model provides for speedy [[Certified first responder|first responder]] response times. Each Hatzalah neighborhood's response time varies. For example, in [[Borough Park, Brooklyn]] daytime response in life threatening emergency are between 1-2 minutes and nighttime response times are 5-6 minutes.<ref name="Bloomberg"/> In the Beverly-La Brea neighborhood of [[Los Angeles]] response times average at sixty to ninety seconds.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.jewishjournal.com/home/preview.php?id=7785 | title= Jewish Journal | year=2001}}</ref>
===Organization=== Hatzalah is not a single organization. Each chapter operates autonomously, or in some cases, with varying levels of affiliation with neighboring Hatzalah chapters.<ref name=Affiliates/><ref name="NYC Branches"/>
In New York City's Hatzalah, there is a very simple operational hierarchy. Usually, there are two or three members who are "coordinators,"<ref name="NYC Struct">{{cite web |url=http://www.hatzalah.org/central.php|title=Regional Locations - Central Coordination}}</ref> managing all operations aspects of the chapter.
As Orthodox Jews, many volunteers see each other daily during [[Jewish services|prayers]], and especially on [[Shabbat]]. This allows them to remain organized despite the lack of an extensive formal hierarchy.
The coordinators are responsible for recruitment, interaction with municipal agency operations (police, fire, and EMS), first-line discipline, and day-to-day operations. The coordinators often are responsible, directly or via delegation, for arranging maintenance crews, who are often called service members or service units, and for purchasing supplies, ambulances, and other equipment. There is also an administrative function, often separate from the coordinator function. The chief administrator is often called a director or [[executive director]], and this is sometimes a paid position. All other positions in Hatzalah, including coordinators, are held by unpaid volunteers.
Most of the New York State branches have some centralized administration and dispatch functions, known as "Central Hatzalah," or simply, "Central." The neighborhood organizations under Central are nevertheless independent. Most Hatzalah organizations pattern themselves after the Williamsburg and Central models (see operational descriptions below).
Formally, the New York City-area "Central Hatzalah" is called Chevra Hatzalah of New York. It combines dispatch and some other functions for over a dozen neighborhood organizations, including<ref name="NYC Branches">{{cite web |title=Regional Branches|url=http://www.hatzalah.org/localBranches.php}}</ref> [[Williamsburg, Brooklyn|Williamsburg]],<ref name=Willie/> [[Flatbush, Brooklyn|Flatbush]], [[Borough Park, Brooklyn|Borough Park]], [[Canarsie]], [[Lower East Side]], [[Upper West Side]], [[Midtown Manhattan|Midtown]], [[Washington Heights, Manhattan|Washington Heights]], [[Queens]], Rockaways & Nassau County, [[Seagate, Brooklyn|Seagate]], [[Catskills]], [[Staten Island]], [[Riverdale, Bronx|Riverdale]], and others. As each of these areas is otherwise independent, each has its own fundraising, management, garages, ambulances, and assigned members. [[Rockland County, New York|Rockland County, NY]] branches have a centralized dispatch system as well, but their [[central organization]] is separate from the other New York State centralized functions, and they have a looser relationship with their New York State brethren, though there is a great deal of cooperation among them. Together, the combined New York State branches have grown to become the largest all-volunteer ambulance system in the United States.<ref name="Bloomberg">{{cite web | url=http://www.nyc.gov/portal/site/nycgov/menuitem.c0935b9a57bb4ef3daf2f1c701c789a0/index.jsp?pageID=mayor_press_release&catID=1194&doc_name=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.nyc.gov%2Fhtml%2Fom%2Fhtml%2F2005a%2Fpr138-05.html&cc=unused1978&rc=1194&ndi=1 | title=Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg Announces Two Initiatives To Redevelop Underutilized Land In The Culver El Section Of Borough Park, Brooklyn | first=M. | last=Bloomberg | year=2005}}</ref>
Within [[Israel]] the largest local organization is [[Magen David Adom]].{{Citation needed|date=March 2017}}
Outside of New York and Israel, there are many smaller Hatzalah organizations. Each of these operates as a self-contained unit, with no centralized organization or coordination. However, where there are other Hatzalahs nearby, there is often a great deal of cooperation.
==Legal status== In the [[United Kingdom]], Hatzalah use [[Emergency vehicle equipment in the United Kingdom|blue lights]] and sirens on their ambulances,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/headlines-breaking-stories/436272/photo-essay-london-ribbon-cutting-ceremony-for-unveiling-of-a-4th-ambulance-for-hatzolah-photos-by-jdn.html|title=Photo Essay: London – Ribbon Cutting Ceremony For Unveiling Of A 4th Ambulance For Hatzolah (Photos by JDN)|date=30 June 2016|publisher=|accessdate=8 May 2018}}</ref> but cannot legally do so on private vehicles.<ref name="Daily Mail">{{cite web | url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2579800/High-Court-upholds-blues-twos-charge-volunteer-paramedics-Jewish-emergency-medical-service.html | title=High Court upholds 'blues-and-twos' charge for volunteer paramedics from Jewish emergency medical service| year=2014}}</ref>
==Community involvement== Hatzalah organizations are often involved in other community activities, on top of their primary mission of emergency medical work. Many neighborhood chapters sponsor and participate in community events, both within the local Jewish community, and in the broader community.
Flatbush Hatzalah frequently plays softball against teams from local police precincts, firehouses, and hospitals.<ref>{{cite web |title=Haztalah Softball |url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/article.php?p=21146}}</ref>
Hatzalah of Passaic/Clifton works with the local Bikur Cholim<ref>{{cite web |title=Passaic/Clifton Health and Safety Fair |url=http://passaichealthandsafetyfair.com }}{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> to put on a yearly Health & Safety Fair at no charge to the community, with participation from both Jewish and non-Jewish presenters, said to get a turnout possibly exceeding 25% of the local community.<ref>{{cite web |title=Health and Safety Fair Press Release |url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/General+News/35385/PHOTOS:+Passaic-Clifton+Health+and+Safety+Fair.html}}</ref>
Many Hatzalahs worldwide<ref>{{cite web |title=Hatzolah Australia Fire Safety|url=http://www.hatzolah.org.au/include/chanukah.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Canadian Hatzoloh Chanukah Safety |url=http://www.hatzoloh.ca/Docs/Chanukah_Safety.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=NYC Haztalah Purim Drinking Campaign |url=http://www.hakhel.info/archivesPublicService/HatzalahPurimSafety.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> run public relations campaigns related to safe drinking on Purim and fire safety on Chanukah and during Passover preparations. Chevra [[Hatzolah]] in New York works closely with the [[FDNY]] on this matter.
==Specialization of Hatzolah EMS== A number of items that are either unique to Hatzalah, or that are relatively unusual for an EMS include: Thumper
===Direct response=== Most EMS rely on crews with scheduled shifts operating from a known location. Due to its members and the communities they serve usually living in proximity, Hatzolah relies little on scheduled crews and stations and rather has all service members on call 24/7 and members responding from wherever they are.<ref>A brief description of their Two-Tier system can be found at [https://www.hatzalah.org/twotiered.php Chevra Hatzalah Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Inc.]</ref>
=== Cultural sensitivities and discrimination === Language, religion, and culture barriers create challenges for an emergency medical service. Hatzalah is built to consider these challenges, especially with regard to [[halacha]] (Jewish law) and communities that only speak [[Yiddish]] or [[Hebrew]].
A Jew reluctant to violate Sabbath rules when receiving medical attention may be more at ease and easily convinced of the medical urgency, when the EMT or paramedic is a fellow [[Orthodox Jew]]. A female worried about physical modesty and contact is helped by knowing that a Jewish provider is aware of the details of her concerns, and will act to reduce the problem as much as possible.
Hatzalah was the subject of controversy as articles in the ''[[New York Post]]''<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/jewish_siren_ladies_Ax71jq2CgYYdWPcFmCzwWN |work=New York Post |first=Reuven |last=Fenton |title=Jewish ‘siren' ladies |date=2011-09-26 |accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref> and ''JEMS Magazine''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.jems.com/article/news/jewish-female-emts-plan-join-all-male-am |title=Jewish Female EMTs Plan to Join All-Male Ambulance Corps - News - @ |publisher=Jems.com |accessdate=2013-09-14}}</ref> criticize the organization for its discriminatory practice of not allowing women to join. The group of Orthodox women founded an organization called “Ezras Nashim” an all-female Orthodox Jewish volunteer [[Emergency medical technician|EMT]] ambulance service,<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/health/jewish-women-brooklyn-launch-ambulance-service-expecting-moms-article-1.1029605|title=Jewish Women in Brooklyn Launch EMT Service|first=Simone|last=Weichselbaum|date=February 27, 2012|newspaper=[[New York Daily News]]}}</ref> they cited the need for modesty and sensitivity to the needs of fellow Orthodox women, with the goal of preserving women’s modesty in emergency medical situations, especially [[childbirth]]. "This is a woman's job. Historically, women have always delivered babies in traditional Jewish values, pointing to the [[Hebrew Bible]] Book of [[Book of Exodus|Exodus]] where the first midwives were women [[Shiphrah]] and [[Puah]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ny1.com/archives/nyc/manhattan/2012/05/28/woman-works-to-form-all-female-hasidic-jewish-emt-service-NYC_162015.old.html|title=Woman Works To Form All-Female Hasidic Jewish EMT Service|first=Michael|last=Herzenberg|date=May 28, 2012|work=[[NY1]]|access-date=2017-01-20|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170131200318/http://www.ny1.com/archives/nyc/manhattan/2012/05/28/woman-works-to-form-all-female-hasidic-jewish-emt-service-NYC_162015.old.html|archive-date=2017-01-31|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> In our community, women also have a very strong motivation to seek female doctors," said their lawyer, [[Rachel Freier]], a Brooklyn Civil Court Judge and Orthodox Jewish mother of six.<ref>{{cite web|author=Joe Levin |url=http://privateinvesigations.blogspot.com/2011/09/orthodox-women-demand-to-join-hatzalah.html |title=T.O.T. Private consulting services: Orthodox Women Demand To Join Hatzalah Ambulances |publisher=Privateinvesigations.blogspot.com |date=2011-09-24 |accessdate=2013-09-14}}</ref>
[[New York State Assembly]] member [[Dov Hikind]] announced on his radio show his support for Ezras Nashim <ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vosizneias.com/91555/2011/09/18/new-york-hatzalah-to-add-ezras-nashim/|title=Hatzalah to Add Ezras Nashim|first=Sandy|last=Eller|work=[[Vosizneias]]|date=September 18, 2011|access-date=September 18, 2011}}</ref> and he was criticized by Hatzalah.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/news/general/103684/op-ed-dov-hikind-takes-on-hatzolahs-daas-torah.html|title=Op-Ed: Dov Hikind Takes On Hatzolah’s Daas Torah|work=[[Yeshiva World News]]|date=19 September 2011}}</ref> The group received approval from their community's leading rabbis, including prominent Rabbi [[Yechezkel Roth]] of Karlsburg.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.vosizneias.com/101010/2012/02/15/new-york-vin-exclusive-prominent-brooklyn-rabbi-endorses-womens-volunteer-medical-corps/|title=Prominent Brooklyn Rabbi Endorses Women’s Volunteer Medical Corps|first=Sandy|last=Eller|work=[[Vosizneias]]|date=February 15, 2012|access-date=February 15, 2012}}</ref> Until now, Hatzolah has operated under this controversial policy, despite receiving public funding, such as the nearly half a million dollars in funding to overhaul the communication system at Hatzolah’s new command center in the Flatbush section of Brooklyn.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vosizneias.com/59939/2010/07/12/brooklyn-ny-flatbush-hatzalah-receives-nearly-half-a-million-grant-from-assemblywoman/ |title=Brooklyn, NY - Hatzalah of New York Receives Nearly Half a Million Grant From Assemblywoman [photos-video |publisher=VosIzNeias.com |accessdate=2013-09-14}}</ref>
===Cost=== In areas where the EMS charges a fee, lower income clientele lacking health insurance may have a reluctance to call for an ambulance unless the evidence of urgency is overwhelming. A volunteer service, with less overhead costs, tends to reduce that reluctance. Hatzolah will often handle "check-out" cases, without charge. In this way, the true emergencies among those check-outs may be recognized and treated quickly, where the caller might have otherwise not sought treatment.<ref name=WhenToCall>{{cite web |url=http://www.hatzolahofla.org/when-to-call |title=Hatzolah LA When To Call Us |publisher=Hatzolah of Los Angeles}}</ref>
===Patient advocacy=== In contrast with most other EMS agencies, many Hatzalah volunteers will remain at the hospital with the patient long after bringing them to the emergency department. This is especially true during serious cases in order to help the patient and/or their families navigate the sometimes confusing series of events that occur during an emergency. Members will stay to explain, advocate and sometimes help make arrangements to bring in other specialists or arrange transfer to higher care facilities.
==Interaction with other agencies== At times there have been difficulties in dealing with outside organizations, including other first-responders.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.crownheights.info/index.php?itemid=35532|title=CrownHeights.info – Chabad News, Crown Heights News, Lubavitch News|work=CrownHeights.info - Chabad News, Crown Heights News, Lubavitch News|accessdate=26 December 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |author=editor, on August 8th, 2012 |url=http://www.catskillscoop.com/2012/08/breaking-hatzolah-members-illegally-ticketed-while-responding-to-life-threatening-emergency.html |title=BREAKING: Hatzolah Members Illegally Ticketed While Responding To Life-Threatening Emergency |publisher=Catskill Scoop |date=2012-08-08 |accessdate=2013-09-14 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120813025250/http://www.catskillscoop.com/2012/08/breaking-hatzolah-members-illegally-ticketed-while-responding-to-life-threatening-emergency.html |archivedate=2012-08-13 |df= }}</ref>
In general, branches have excellent relations with state and local police and EMS.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://collive.com/show_news.rtx?id=16819 |title=Missing 12 Year-Old Boy Found |publisher=Collive.com |accessdate=2013-09-14}}</ref>
An example of those operating in uneven<ref>e.g. seasonal</ref> or otherwise especially challenging situations<ref>Israel's [[United Hatzalah]], see below</ref> is Catskills Hatzolah, handling the swelling summer crowd.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.twitpic.com/photos/911BUFF?page=6 |title=Twitpic / 911BUFF |publisher=Twitpic.com |accessdate=2013-09-14}}</ref><ref>In the Catskills: A Century of the Jewish Experience, {{ISBN|0-231123-612}}, p. 339</ref>
Israel's [[United Hatzalah]] has shared its expertise with a group of [[Arab]] volunteers from [[East Jerusalem]] to form an emergency first response unit called Nuran. The group since has been dismantled and the volunteers were incorporated in United Hatzalah.
United Hatzalah's relationship with [[Magen David Adom]], however, is strained, and MDA has banned its members and volunteers from also volunteering in other rescue organizations, including Hatzalah.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-3685792,00.html |title=Haredi Rescue Organizations Collapsing |publisher=[[Ynetnews]] |author=Gilhar, Uri |date=March 13, 2009 |accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref>
The Chevra NYC Central affiliates boast an excellent relationship with New York City and New York State agencies.<ref name="NYC Ops">{{cite web |title=Fastest Response Times in the World |url=http://www.hatzalah.org/twotiered.php |accessdate=6 June 2012}}</ref>
On February 20, 2013, the [[Federal Communications Commission]] granted Chevrah Hatzalah's request for a waiver to obtain calling party numbers (CPN) even when callers have [[Caller ID blocking#Blocking|caller ID blocking]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Petition of Chevrah Hatzalah Volunteer Ambulance Corps Inc. for Waiver of Section 1601(b) of the Commission’s Rules – Blocked Telephone Numbers|url=http://transition.fcc.gov/Daily_Releases/Daily_Business/2013/db0220/DA-13-227A1.pdf |format=PDF}}</ref> Calls to [[9-1-1|911]] are exempt from CPN blocking but calls to Chevrah Hatzalah do not go through 911. Other Hatzalah dispatch numbers, including other New York State Hatzalah groups, do not have this waiver, but some are working on it.
==September 11, 2001== Hatzalah members were among the first responders to the [[World Trade Center (1973–2001)|World Trade Center]] on [[September 11, 2001]].<ref name=102m>A number of Hatzoloh volunteers wearing "Flatbush Hatzoloh Paramedics" uniforms are featured in the documentary film ''[[102 Minutes That Changed America]]''.</ref> Alongside other rescue workers, Hatzalah volunteers rescued, treated, and transported countless victims of the terrorist attack.<ref name="102m"/> In the process they earned great respect from their peers in the emergency service community.<ref name="kelty">{{cite web |title=Jimmy Kelty |url=http://www.hatzalah.org/duringAttack.php |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68E8KP0Ss?url=http://www.hatzalah.org/duringAttack.php |archivedate=2012-06-06 |accessdate=6 June 2012 |df= }}</ref>
Hatzalah was not dispatched by the city's 911 system, and a printout of the 911 job from FDNY EMS does not list them as responding units.<ref>FDNY Call 0727 MCI40P Aircraft Incident/ Crash PDJob#01225500590 Date 9/11/01</ref> However, audio recordings exist of Hatzalah's own dispatch, including members calling for help during the collapse of the first tower.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theyeshivaworld.com/article.php?p=23347 |title=The Yeshiva World Audio Of Hatzolah Radio & Video: 7 Years Since 9/11 |publisher=Theyeshivaworld.com |date=2008-09-11 |accessdate=2013-09-14}}</ref> There are also well-known photos of destroyed Hatzalah ambulances<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bphatzolah.org/911hatzalah011.jpg|title=Image: One of the Hatzolah ambulances destroyed on 9-11] (JPG 650x425 77.0 KB), from [http://www.bphatzolah.org/911album.html Boro Park Hatzolah – Sept. 11 Album|publisher=|accessdate=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160303225256/http://www.bphatzolah.org/911hatzalah011.jpg|archive-date=2016-03-03|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>The Hatzalah ambulance donated by NYS Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver in memory of his parents protected early Hatzalah responders, but was subsequently destroyed by falling debris after they were evacuated. [http://www.thirteen.org/metrofocus/2011/09/my-911-a-new-york-united/ Sheldon Silver: My 9/11: A New York United – Thirteen]</ref> and the destroyed cars of Hatzalah members, in the aftermath of the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bphatzolah.org/911hatzalah01.jpg|title=Image: Members cars piled up] (JPG 420x243 35.8 KB) from [http://www.bphatzolah.org/911album.html Boro Park Hatzolah – Sept. 11 Album|publisher=|accessdate=8 May 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304035407/http://www.bphatzolah.org/911hatzalah01.jpg|archive-date=2016-03-04|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref> The Hatzalah units were also referred to in a memoir of 9/11 by responding NYC fireman [[Dennis Smith (firefighter)|Dennis Smith]] in his book ''Report From Ground Zero''. On page 231 of the first edition he wrote: "I met two guys from Engine 39. They brought me to EMS, the Hezbollah [sic] ambulance." This was corrected in later editions.
==Chapters== {{For|a full listing of Hatzalah chapters|List of Hatzolah chapters}}
Chapters of the organization exist in Argentina, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, England, Israel, Mexico, Russia, South Africa, Switzerland, and in the United States. The chapters in each neighborhood or city operate independently though in many cases affiliations and levels of cooperation do exist between neighboring chapters.<ref name=Affiliates/><ref>NYC Regional branches can be found at [https://www.hatzalah.org/localBranches.php Chevra Hatzalah Volunteer Ambulance Corps, Inc.]</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Hatzolah chapters]] *[[Shomrim (volunteers)|Shomrim]] and Shmira ( "custodian" or "guardian" ) citizen patrol organizations *[[Chaverim (volunteers)|Chaverim]] (literally, "Friends") roadside assistance squads *[[ZAKA]] ''Zihuy Korbanot Ason'' (literally: "Disaster Victim Identification")
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.unitedhatzalah.org/?CategoryID=226&ArticleID=280 United Hatzalah, Israel] * [http://www.hatzolahdarom.org/ Hatzolah Darom, Israel] * [http://www.hatzolahofla.org Hatzolah of Los Angeles] * [http://www.hatzalahchicago.org Hatzolah of Chicago] * [http://www.hatzalahems.com Hatzalah of the Jersey Shore] * [http://www.hatzolah.com.au Hatzolah of Sydney, Australia] * [http://hatzolah.org.au// Chevra Hatzolah of Melbourne, Australia] * [http://www.hatzalah.com.mx/ Chevra Hatzolah of Mexico City] * [http://www.hatzolah.co.za/ Hatzolah of Johannesburg, South Africa] * [http://www.hazoloh.ch/ Hatzolah of Zurich, Switzerland] * [http://www.hatzoloh.be/ Hatzolah of Antwerpn, Belgium] * [http://detroithatzalah.org/ Hatzalah of Detroit, Michigan] {{Organized Jewish Life in the United States}}
[[Category:Ambulance services]] [[Category:Ambulance services in the United States]] [[Category:Ambulance services in Australia]] [[Category:Emergency services in Israel]] [[Category:First aid organizations]] [[Category:Jewish medical organizations]] [[Category:Volunteer search and rescue organisations]] [[Category:Ambulance services in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:International volunteer organizations]]

Germany ranked 20th in the world in [[life expectancy]] in 2014 with [[List of countries by life expectancy|76.5 years for men and 82.1 years for women]]. It had a very low [[infant mortality rate]] (4.3 per 1,000 [[Live birth (human)|live births]]), and it was eighth place in the number of practicing physicians, at per 1,000 people (3.3).
A new measure of expected [[human capital]] calculated for 195 countries from 1990 to 2016 and defined for each birth cohort as the expected years lived from age 20 to 64 years and adjusted for educational attainment, learning or education quality, and functional health status was published by [[The Lancet]] in September 2018. Germany had the twenty-fourth highest level of expected human capital with 25 health, education, and learning-adjusted expected years lived between age 20 and 64 years. <ref>{{cite news |last1=Lim |first1=Stephen |last2=et |first2=al |title=Measuring human capital: a systematic analysis of 195 countries and territories, 1990–2016 |url=https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(18)31941-X/fulltext |accessdate=5 November 2018 |publisher=Lancet}}</ref>
==Epidemiology==
At the end of 2004, some 44,900 Germans, or less than 0.1 percent of the population, were infected with human immunodeficiency virus/acquired immune deficiency syndrome ([[HIV/AIDS]]). In the first half of 2005, German health authorities registered 1,164 new infections; about 60 percent of the cases involved homosexual men. Since the beginning of the HIV/AIDS epidemic, about 24,000 Germans have died from the disease.
According to a 2013 micro-census survey, 24.5% of the German population aged 15+ are smokers (29 percent in men, 20 percent in women).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.destatis.de/DE/PresseService/Presse/Pressemitteilungen/2014/11/PD14_386_239.html |title=Jeder zweite Erwachsene in Deutschland hat Übergewicht |author= |date=2014-11-05 |language=de |website=destatis.de |page= |publisher=Statistisches Bundesamt |access-date=2015-06-24}}</ref> Among the 18- to 25-year-old age group, 35.2% are smokers.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ibtimes.com/german-youths-smoking-less-tobacco-industry-remains-powerful-1320561 |title=German Youths Smoking Less, But Tobacco Industry Remains Powerful |author=Palash Ghosh |date=2013-06-24 |website= |page= |publisher=IBT Media Inc. |access-date=2015-06-24}}</ref>
[[Obesity]] in Germany has been increasingly cited as a major health issue. A 2007 study shows Germany has the highest number of overweight people in Europe.<ref name="DW1">{{cite news|title=Topping the EU Fat Stats, Germany Plans Anti-Obesity Drive|url=http://www.dw-world.de/dw/article/0,,2449356,00.html|publisher=Deutsche Welle|date=20 April 2007|accessdate=25 June 2010}}</ref><ref name="BBC1">{{cite news|title=Germany launches obesity campaign|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/health/6639227.stm|publisher=BBC |date=9 May 2007|accessdate =25 June 2010}}</ref> However, the United Kingdom, Greece and certain countries in Eastern Europe have a higher rate of "truly obese" people.<ref name="Spiegel1">{{cite news|title=Germans Are Fattest People in Europe, Study Shows|url=http://www.spiegel.de/international/europe/0,1518,478303,00.html|work=Der Spiegel |date=19 April 2007|accessdate=26 June 2010}}</ref> Forbes.com ranks Germany as the 43rd fattest country in the World with a rate of 60.1%.<ref name="Forbes1">{{cite news|title=World's Fattest Countries|url=https://www.forbes.com/2007/02/07/worlds-fattest-countries-forbeslife-cx_ls_0208worldfat_2.html|work=Forbes|date=8 February 2007|accessdate=25 June 2010}}</ref>
In 2015 it was estimated that 11.52% of the population has diabetes, costing about $4,943 per person per year.<ref>{{cite news|title=Top 10: Which country has the highest rates of diabetes in Europe? The UK’s position might surprise you…|url=http://www.diabetes.co.uk/blog/2015/08/which-country-highest-diabetes-europe/|accessdate=20 December 2015|publisher=Diabetes UK|date=27 August 2015}}</ref>
==History== At the end of the nineteenth century Berlin had the highest urban density of any city in Europe.Only 8% of dwellings in the city had a toilet. There were repeated outbreaks of cholera and typhus. [[Rudolf Virchow]] promoted sewage works, called [[Rieselfel]]der, after the cholera epidemic of 1868. In 1871 a smallpox epidemic killed 6478 people. Virchow estimated that 5% of the Berlin population were infected by venereal disease.
Tuberculosis was estimated to be the cause of about 15% of all deaths in Prussia in 1860.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Richie |first1=Alexandra |title=Faust's Metropolis |date=1998 |publisher=Carroll & Graf |location=New York |isbn=0-7867-0510-8 |page=164 }}</ref>
==Vaccination== In Germany, the [[Standing Committee on Vaccination]] is the federal commission responsible for recommending an immunization schedule. The [[Robert Koch Institute]] in Berlin (RKI) compiles data of immunization status upon the entry of children at school, and measures vaccine coverage of Germany at a national level.<ref name="Germany">{{cite web|title=Germany|url=http://venice.cineca.org/documents/germany_ip.pdf|website=Vaccination European New Integrated Collaboration Effort|publisher=Venice III}}</ref> Founded in 1972, the STIKO is composed of 12–18 volunteers, appointed members by the [[Federal Ministry of Health (Germany)|Federal Ministry for Health]] for 3-year terms.<ref>{{cite web|title=The German Standing Committee of Vaccination|url=http://www.rki.de/EN/Content/infections/Vaccination/Vaccination_node.html|publisher=Robert Koch Institut}}</ref> The independent advisory group meets biannually to address issues pertaining to preventable infectious diseases.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vaccinations|url=http://www.english.g-ba.de/special-topics/vaccinations/|website=G-BA|publisher=Bermeinsamer Bundesausschuss|access-date= 15 March 2016}}</ref> Although the STIKO makes recommendations, immunization in Germany is voluntary and there are no official government recommendations. [[States of Germany|German Federal States]] typically follow the Standing Vaccination Committee's recommendations minimally, although each state can make recommendations for their geographic jurisdiction that extends beyond the recommended list.<ref name="Germany"/> In addition to the proposed immunization schedule for children and adults, the STIKO recommends vaccinations for occupational groups, police, travelers, and other at risk groups.<ref name="Germany"/> Vaccinations recommendations that are issued must be in accordance with the Protection Against Infection Act ([[:de:Infektionsschutzgesetz|Infektionsschutzgesetz]]), which regulates the prevention of infectious diseases in humans.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Kerwat K, Just M, Wulf H | title = [The German Protection against Infection Act (Infektionsschutzgesetz (IfSG))] | journal = Anasthesiologie, Intensivmedizin, Notfallmedizin, Schmerztherapie | volume = 44 | issue = 3 | pages = 182–3 | date = March 2009 | pmid = 19266418 | doi = 10.1055/s-0029-1215548 }}</ref> If a vaccination is recommended because of occupational risks, it must adhere to the [http://www.cgerli.org/index.php?id=50&tx_vmdocumentsearch_pi2%5BdocID%5D=1502 Occupational Safety and Health Act involving Biological Agents].<ref name="STIKO at the Robert Koch">{{cite web|title=Recommendations of the Standing Committee on Vaccinations STIKO at the Robert Koch Institute|url=http://www.rki.de/EN/Content/infections/Vaccination/recommandations/34_2015_engl.pdf?__blob=publicationFile|website=Epidemiologisches Bulletin|publisher=Robert Koch Institute }}</ref> In the event of vaccination related injuries, federal states are responsible for monetary compensation.<ref name="STIKO at the Robert Koch"/> Germany's central government does not finance childhood immunizations, so 90% of vaccines are administered in a private physician's office and paid for through insurance. The other 10% of vaccines are provided by the states in public health clinics, schools, or day care centers by local immunization programs.<ref name="Germany"/> Physician responsibilities concerning immunization include beginning infancy vaccination, administering booster vaccinations, maintaining medical and vaccination history, and giving information and recommendations concerning vaccines.<ref name="STIKO at the Robert Koch"/>
==See also== [[Healthcare in Germany]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Health in Germany]]

revision.comment: Reverted to revision 849473729 by [[Special:Contributions/Cydebot|Cydebot]] ([[User talk:Cydebot|talk]]): Bad source. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
[[File:Desktop Computer - The Future for Medicine (FDA 095) (8249708093).jpg|thumb|right|a 1984 United States advertisement for access to health information through the 1980s [[Apple III]]]] '''Health information on the Internet''' refers to all communication related to health done on the [[Internet]].
==Types== As a general communication channel, various Internet products serve every type of general health information.
===Targeting types of information to different audiences=== In the late 1990s researchers began to note that huge numbers of people were using the Internet to seek health information, despite various problems with the quality of information or inefficiencies in accessing it.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Risk | first1 = A. | last2 = Petersen | first2 = C. | doi = 10.1001/jama.287.20.2713 | title = Health Information on the Internet | journal = JAMA | volume = 287 | issue = 20 | pages = 2713–2715 | year = 2002 | pmid = 12020308| pmc = }}</ref> Various problems have been identified for those using [[search engines]] to seek health information.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Berland | first1 = G. K. | last2 = Elliott | first2 = M. N. | last3 = Morales | first3 = L. S. | last4 = Algazy | first4 = J. I. | last5 = Kravitz | first5 = R. L. | last6 = Broder | first6 = M. S. | last7 = Kanouse | first7 = D. E. | last8 = Muñoz | first8 = J. A. | last9 = Puyol | first9 = J. A. | last10 = Lara | first10 = M. | last11 = Watkins | first11 = K. E. | last12 = Yang | first12 = H. | last13 = McGlynn | first13 = E. A. | title = Health Information on the Internet | doi = 10.1001/jama.285.20.2612 | journal = JAMA | volume = 285 | issue = 20 | pages = 2612–2621 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11368735| pmc = 4182102}}</ref>
There is a premise that patients with access to their personal health information presented in a form they can understand will be able to interpret and learn from this information in a way that benefits them.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Beaudin|first=JS|author2=Intille, SS |author3=Morris, ME |title=To track or not to track: user reactions to concepts in longitudinal health monitoring.|journal=Journal of medical Internet research|year=2006|volume=8|issue=4|pages=e29|pmid=17236264|pmc=1794006|doi=10.2196/jmir.8.4.e29}}</ref> Physicians worry that patients using their own medical history records as a starting point for personal research on the Internet are at risk for being overwhelmed and misinformed when seeking health information on the Internet.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Robeznieks|first=A|title=Getting personal. Legal liability, patient-data overload among issues making physicians uneasy over emergence of personal health records.|journal=Modern healthcare|date=May 21, 2007|volume=37|issue=21|pages=40–2|pmid=17824189}}</ref>
As of 2013 opinions about the relationship health care providers should have with online health information were still being established.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Farnan|first=Jeanne M.|title=Online Medical Professionalism: Patient and Public Relationships: Policy Statement From the American College of Physicians and the Federation of State Medical Boards|journal=Annals of Internal Medicine|date=16 April 2013|volume=158|issue=8|pages=620–7|doi=10.7326/0003-4819-158-8-201304160-00100|pmid=23579867}}</ref> According to one 2014 study, "The flow of information has fundamentally changed, and physicians have less control over health information relayed to patients. Not surprisingly, this paradigm shift has elicited varied and sometimes conflicting views about the value of the Internet as a tool to improve health care."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Tonsaker|first=Tabitha|last2=Bartlett|first2=Gillian|last3=Trpkov|first3=Cvetan|date=2016-11-14|title=Health information on the Internet|journal=Canadian Family Physician|volume=60|issue=5|pages=407–408|issn=0008-350X|pmc=4020634|pmid=24828994}}</ref>
[[Social media]] channels have been noted as places which physicians can visit to get insight on patient thoughts.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Verhoef|first=Lise M |author2=Van de Belt, Tom H |author3=Engelen, Lucien JLPG |author4=Schoonhoven, Lisette |author5=Kool, Rudolf B |title=Social Media and Rating Sites as Tools to Understanding Quality of Care: A Scoping Review|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|date=20 February 2014|volume=16|issue=2|pages=e56|doi=10.2196/jmir.3024|pmid=24566844 |pmc=3961699}}</ref> Patients have increasingly turned to social media for health information, sometimes of dubious quality.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Prybutok|first=Gayle|last2=Ryan|first2=Sherry|date=2015-04-01|title=Social media: the key to health information access for 18- to 30-year-old college students|journal=Computers, informatics, nursing: CIN|volume=33|issue=4|pages=132–141|doi=10.1097/CIN.0000000000000147|issn=1538-9774|pmid=25887107}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Lau|first=A. Y. S.|last2=Siek|first2=K. A.|last3=Fernandez-Luque|first3=L.|last4=Tange|first4=H.|last5=Chhanabhai|first5=P.|last6=Li|first6=S. Y. W.|last7=Elkin|first7=P. L.|last8=Arjabi|first8=A.|last9=Walczowski|first9=L.|date=2011-01-01|title=The role of social media for patients and consumer health|url=https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Annie_Lau2/publication/51662040_The_Role_of_Social_Media_for_Patients_and_Consumer_Health_Contribution_of_the_IMIA_Consumer_Health_Informatics_Working_Group/links/54dcb1140cf28a3d93f84972.pdf|journal=IMIA Yearbook|volume=6|issue=1|pages=131–138}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Fernández-Luque|first=Luis|last2=Bau|first2=Teresa|date=2015-01-01|title=Health and social media: perfect storm of information|url=http://synapse.koreamed.org/search.php?where=aview&id=10.4258/hir.2015.21.2.67&code=1088HIR&vmode=FULL|journal=Healthcare informatics research|volume=21|issue=2|pages=67–73|doi=10.4258/hir.2015.21.2.67|pmid=25995958|pmc=4434065}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Helve|first=Otto|last2=Kattelus|first2=Mervi|last3=Norhomaa|first3=Samuli|last4=Saarni|first4=Samuli|date=2015-01-01|title=[Health information and social media: the doctor as a primary school teacher again]|journal=Duodecim; Laaketieteellinen Aikakauskirja|volume=131|issue=21|pages=2003–2008|issn=0012-7183|pmid=26677551}}</ref> Several studies have used social media to gather data on patients' [[adverse drug reaction]]s (ADRs), with generally promising results.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Sarker|first=Abeed|last2=Ginn|first2=Rachel|last3=Nikfarjam|first3=Azadeh|last4=O'Connor|first4=Karen|last5=Smith|first5=Karen|last6=Jayaraman|first6=Swetha|last7=Upadhaya|first7=Tejaswi|last8=Gonzalez|first8=Graciela|date=2015-04-01|title=Utilizing social media data for pharmacovigilance: A review|journal=Journal of Biomedical Informatics|volume=54|pages=202–212|doi=10.1016/j.jbi.2015.02.004|issn=1532-0480|pmc=4408239|pmid=25720841}}</ref>
Various commercial organizations use health information gathered from the Internet. The use of health information gathered from social media has been described as raising serious ethical and privacy concerns,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Denecke|first=K.|last2=Bamidis|first2=P.|last3=Bond|first3=C.|last4=Gabarron|first4=E.|last5=Househ|first5=M.|last6=Lau|first6=A. Y. S.|last7=Mayer|first7=M. A.|last8=Merolli|first8=M.|last9=Hansen|first9=M.|date=2015-08-13|title=Ethical Issues of Social Media Usage in Healthcare|journal=Yearbook of Medical Informatics|volume=10|issue=1|pages=137–147|doi=10.15265/IY-2015-001|issn=0943-4747|pmc=4587037|pmid=26293861}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Moorhead|first=S Anne|last2=Hazlett|first2=Diane E|last3=Harrison|first3=Laura|last4=Carroll|first4=Jennifer K|last5=Irwin|first5=Anthea|last6=Hoving|first6=Ciska|date=2013-04-23|title=A New Dimension of Health Care: Systematic Review of the Uses, Benefits, and Limitations of Social Media for Health Communication|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|volume=15|issue=4|doi=10.2196/jmir.1933|issn=1439-4456|pmc=3636326|pmid=23615206|pages=e85}}</ref> including the risk of accidental violations of patient privacy by health care providers on social media.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ventola|first=C. Lee|date=2016-11-14|title=Social Media and Health Care Professionals: Benefits, Risks, and Best Practices|journal=Pharmacy and Therapeutics|volume=39|issue=7|pages=491–520|issn=1052-1372|pmc=4103576|pmid=25083128}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Shay|first=Daniel F.|date=2014-08-25|title=Physician use of social media: navigating the risks. Establish social media guidelines to protect health information, and reputation of practice and physicians|journal=Medical Economics|volume=91|issue=16|pages=44–46|issn=0025-7206|pmid=25509476}}</ref>
==={{anchor|Educational resources for layman audiences}} Educational resources for lay audiences===
====Background on the doctor–patient relationship==== {{main article|Doctor–patient relationship}} Physicians have difficulty explaining complicated medical concepts to their patients and patients have difficulty understanding complicated things which physicians tell them. One reasons for this is that a patient's visit to a physician is likely to be less than 15 minutes, and in any case, physicians are unable to spend the amount of time which patients that patients typically desire.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Mechanic|first=David|author2=McAlpine, Donna D. |author3=Rosenthal, Marsha |title=Are Patients' Office Visits with Physicians Getting Shorter?|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|date=18 January 2001|volume=344|issue=3|pages=198–204|doi=10.1056/NEJM200101183440307|pmid=11172143}}</ref> Physicians use medical terms which patients do not understand, but which they would like to learn.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Castro|first=CM|author2=Wilson, C |author3=Wang, F |author4= Schillinger, D |title=Babel babble: physicians' use of unclarified medical jargon with patients|journal=American journal of health behavior|date=Sep–Oct 2007|volume=31 Suppl 1|pages=S85–95|pmid=17931142 |doi=10.5993/ajhb.31.s1.11}}</ref> There is consensus that patients should have [[shared decision making]], which means that they make informed decisions about the direction of their health care in collaboration with their physician.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Braddock III|first=Clarence H.|author2=Edwards, Kelly A. |author3=Hasenberg, Nicole M. |author4=Laidley, Tracy L. |author5= Levinson, Wendy |title=Informed Decision Making in Outpatient Practice|journal=JAMA|date=22 December 1999|volume=282|issue=24|pages=2313–20|doi=10.1001/jama.282.24.2313|pmid=10612318}}</ref> Rich, educated, socially advantaged patients enjoy many more benefits of shared decision making than patients who have disadvantages in getting healthcare, including lower socioeconomic class or having a minority status.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fiscella|first=Kevin|author2=Epstein, Ronald M.|title=So Much to Do, So Little Time:care for the socially disadvantaged and the 15-minute visit |journal=Archives of Internal Medicine|date=22 September 2008|volume=168|issue=17|pages=1843–52|doi=10.1001/archinte.168.17.1843|pmid=18809810|pmc=2606692}}</ref>
Lack of patient understanding of health contributes to a range of problems including tendency to not adhere to the physician's medical advice and missing medical appointments.<ref name="Wicks 2010">A better source should be used to support this claim, although this source is good enough for how it is used here. *{{cite journal|last=Wicks|first=Paul|author2=Massagli, Michael |author3=Frost, Jeana |author4=Brownstein, Catherine |author5=Okun, Sally |author6=Vaughan, Timothy |author7=Bradley, Richard |author8= Heywood, James |title=Sharing Health Data for Better Outcomes on PatientsLikeMe|journal=Journal of Medical Internet Research|date=14 June 2010|volume=12|issue=2|pages=e19|doi=10.2196/jmir.1549 |pmid=20542858 |pmc=2956230}}</ref> Patients without access to health information are also more likely to use [[complementary and alternative medicine]] which is not [[evidence-based medicine]] and to fail to inform their physician that they are doing so.<ref name="Wicks 2010"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Robinson|first=A|author2=McGrail, MR|title=Disclosure of CAM use to medical practitioners: a review of qualitative and quantitative studies.|journal=Complementary therapies in medicine|date=Jun–Sep 2004|volume=12|issue=2–3|pages=90–8|pmid=15561518|doi=10.1016/j.ctim.2004.09.006}}</ref> While some benefits can be gained by training physicians to be more efficient in serving patients, there are also benefits in training patients to be more efficient in getting benefits from physicians and there are arguments that encouraging efficient patient behavior is a powerful strategy for improving health care processes.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Lorig|first=K|title=Partnerships between expert patients and physicians.|journal=Lancet|date=Mar 9, 2002|volume=359|issue=9309|pages=814–5|pmid=11897275|doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(02)07959-X}}</ref>
====Resources==== Various social forums exist in which anyone can have conversations about health with their peers. Such forums are especially popular among patients who seek to have conversations with other patients with a shared medical concern.<ref name="Eysenbach 2004">{{cite journal|last=Eysenbach|first=G.|title=Health related virtual communities and electronic support groups: systematic review of the effects of online peer to peer interactions|journal=BMJ|date=15 May 2004|volume=328|issue=7449|pages=1166–0|doi=10.1136/bmj.328.7449.1166|pmid=15142921|pmc=411092}}</ref> Those who participate in online communities which discuss health issues report feeling relief about their health worries, perceiving more control over their health and medical condition, having more medical knowledge, and having more personal agency overall.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Barak|first=Azy|author2=Boniel-Nissim, Meyran |author3=Suler, John |title=Fostering empowerment in online support groups|journal=Computers in Human Behavior|date=September 2008|volume=24|issue=5|pages=1867–1883|doi=10.1016/j.chb.2008.02.004}}</ref>
Some research has failed to find evidence to validate physicians' concerns that patients typically receive misinformation online or using health information to inappropriately conduct [[self diagnosis]].<ref name="Eysenbach 2004"/><ref>{{cite journal|last=Ahmad|first=F|author2=Hudak, PL |author3=Bercovitz, K |author4=Hollenberg, E |author5= Levinson, W |title=Are physicians ready for patients with Internet-based health information?|journal=Journal of medical Internet research|date=Sep 29, 2006|volume=8|issue=3|pages=e22|pmid=17032638 |doi=10.2196/jmir.8.3.e22 |pmc=2018833}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|last=Crocco|first=AG|author2=Villasis-Keever, M |author3=Jadad, AR |title=Analysis of cases of harm associated with use of health information on the internet|journal=JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association|date=Jun 5, 2002|volume=287|issue=21|pages=2869–71|pmid=12038937|doi=10.1001/jama.287.21.2869}}</ref> Patients with chronic diseases who use the Internet to get health information often acquire good skills to judge the quality of information which they find.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Stevenson|first=FA|author2=Kerr, C |author3=Murray, E |author4= Nazareth, I |title=Information from the Internet and the doctor-patient relationship: the patient perspective--a qualitative study.|journal=BMC Family Practice|date=Aug 16, 2007|volume=8|pages=47|pmid=17705836 |doi=10.1186/1471-2296-8-47 |pmc=2041946}}</ref>
===Academic medical literature=== The written record of medical consensus is stored in [[scientific journals]]. Since the advent of [[electronic publishing]] there has been [[academic journal publishing reform]] which had a range of effects, including more researchers and physicians having greater access to professional information in medical journals through the Internet.
===Patients' personal health information=== Through various sources both publicly and privately available, datasets containing health information about large numbers of patients are available on the Internet to an extent which was impossible to manage before the Internet.
==Quality== Measures and standards for ensuring quality control on the Internet have been criticized and no one standard is universally accepted.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Jadad | first1 = A. R. | last2 = Gagliardi | first2 = A. | doi = 10.1001/jama.279.8.611 | title = Rating Health Information on the Internet | journal = JAMA | volume = 279 | issue = 8 | pages = 611–614 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9486757| pmc = }}</ref> Regardless of what kind of measure is used, much health information on the Internet is of dubious quality.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1136/bmj.324.7337.557 | last1 = Purcell | first1 = G. P. | last2 = Wilson | first2 = P. | last3 = Delamothe | first3 = T. | title = The quality of health information on the internet | journal = BMJ (Clinical research ed.) | volume = 324 | issue = 7337 | pages = 557–558 | year = 2002 | pmid = 11884303 | pmc = 1122494 }}</ref> Among all sources there is a wide variance in quality of health information on the Internet.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Fahy|first=E|author2=Hardikar, R |author3=Fox, A |author4= Mackay, S |title=Quality of patient health information on the Internet: reviewing a complex and evolving landscape.|journal=The Australasian medical journal|year=2014|volume=7|issue=1|pages=24–28|pmid=24567763 |doi=10.4066/AMJ.2014.1900 |pmc=3920473}}</ref> The nature and quality of online health-related information seeking on the web is challenging and complex and many researchers investigated this issue benefiting from a wide range of theories from different disciplines.</ref> Among all sources there is a wide variance in quality of health information on the Internet.<ref>Khosrowjerdi, M. (2016). A review of theory-driven models of trust in the online health context. IFLA Journal, 42(3): pp. 189-206. http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1177/0340035216659299</ref>
==Personal health information== For many applications people wish to use health information on the Internet to give insight about a personal health concern. Because of this, the goal is often to use the Internet to find information described in a person's [[medical record]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} Since the advent of [[electronic media]], medical records have been increasingly kept as [[electronic medical records]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} If electronic medical records were shared online then it would be easy to match those with information and conduct a range of research.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Pagliari|first=C|author2=Detmer, D |author3=Singleton, P |title=Potential of electronic personal health records.|journal=BMJ (Clinical research ed.)|date=Aug 18, 2007|volume=335|issue=7615|pages=330–3|pmid=17703042|doi=10.1136/bmj.39279.482963.AD|pmc=1949437}}</ref> However, all medical records are [[protected health information]] because sharing personal health information exposes an individual to a range of harms which result from violation of their [[expectation of privacy]].{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
There is currently broad international debate about how to balance patient and commercial medicine demands for personal health information with individual's needs for safety and respect.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
===Electronic medical records=== {{main article|Electronic medical record}} An electronic medical record is a [[medical record]] stored as [[electronic media]].<ref>{{cite journal|last=Tang|first=P. C|author2=Ash, J. S |author3=Bates, D. W |author4=Overhage, J M. |author5= Sands, D. Z |title=Personal Health Records: Definitions, Benefits, and Strategies for Overcoming Barriers to Adoption|journal=Journal of the American Medical Informatics Association|date=1 March 2006|volume=13|issue=2|pages=121–126|doi=10.1197/jamia.M2025 |pmid=16357345 |pmc=1447551}}</ref>
===De-identification=== {{main article|De-identification}} De-identification is an attempt to divide a collection of information about a particular person so that all information which identifies the person is removed, and with intent to distribute whatever information is left. The closer the data is to [[anonymization]] the less valuable the data is to those who want it, so in general, data is only de-identified somewhat and rarely anonymized. There are many controversies in de-identification.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
===Research using personal health information=== There is a large demand for access to large collections of various types of personal health information.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}} Almost all of this demand is commercial.{{citation needed|date=March 2014}}
===Distribution of collections of personal health information=== Various groups have expressed worry over danger to the public which results from the distribution of collections of personal health information.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/technology/blog/2013/jun/05/data-protection-eu-anonymous |title=Data protection in the EU: the certainty of uncertainty |first=Cory |last=Doctorow |authorlink=Cory Doctorow |work=theguardian.com |date=5 June 2013 |accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref>
In 2014 [[National Health Service]] in the United Kingdom proposed to sell datasets of personal health information.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.theguardian.com/society/2014/jan/19/nhs-patient-data-available-companies-buy |title=NHS patient data to be made available for sale to drug and insurance firms |first=Randeep |last=Ramesh |work=theguardian.com |date=19 January 2014 |accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.wired.co.uk/news/archive/2014-02/04/care-data-nhs-healthcare |title=Thanks to Care.data, your secrets are no longer safe with your GP (Wired UK) |first=Asher |last=Wolf |work=wired.co.uk |date=7 February 2014|accessdate=31 March 2014}}</ref>
==Major providers of health information on the Internet== ===PubMed=== {{main article|PubMed}} PubMed is a free search engine accessing primarily the [[MEDLINE]] database of references and abstracts on life sciences and biomedical topics. The [[United States National Library of Medicine]] at the [[National Institutes of Health]] maintains the database.
===Wikipedia=== {{main article|Health information on Wikipedia}} In 2014 Wikipedia was described as "the leading single source of healthcare information for patients and healthcare professionals".<ref>Note - sketchy link requires registration. {{cite book|title=Engaging patients through social media Is healthcare ready for empowered and digitally demanding patients?|year=2014|publisher=[[IMS Health]]|pages=16–26|url=http://www.imshealth.com/portal/site/imshealth/menuitem.762a961826aad98f53c753c71ad8c22a/?vgnextoid=505cde0fdbc73410VgnVCM10000076192ca2RCRD&vgnextchannel=736de5fda6370410VgnVCM10000076192ca2RCRD&vgnextfmt=default|author=[[IMS Health]]|accessdate=22 January 2014|chapter=The use of Wikipedia in Health Care}} Further cited in *{{cite web |url= https://www.npr.org/2014/02/08/273680018/dr-wikipedia-the-double-edged-sword-of-crowd-sourced-medicine |title=Dr. Wikipedia: The 'Double-Edged Sword' Of Crowd-Sourced Medicine |author=NPR staff |work=npr.org |publisher=[[NPR]] |date=8 February 2014 |accessdate=10 February 2014}} *{{cite web |url= http://qz.com/171162/americas-future-doctors-are-starting-their-careers-by-saving-wikipedia/ |title=America’s future doctors are starting their careers by saving Wikipedia |first=Rachel |last=Feltman |work=[[Quartz (publication)|qz.com]] |date=28 January 2014 |accessdate=5 February 2014}} *{{cite web |url= http://www.newsmax.com/Reagan/Doctors-Wikipedia-online-healthcare/2014/01/31/id/550164 |title=Wikipedia Shouldn't be Doctors' online healthcare source |first=Michael |last=Reagan |authorlink=Michael Reagan |work=[[Newsmax Media|newsmax.com]] |date=31 Jan 2014 |accessdate=5 February 2014}} *{{cite web |url= http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/820249 |title=Doctors, Not Just Patients, Use Wikipedia, Too: IMS Report |first=Miriam E. |last=Tucker |work=[[Medscape]] |date=5 February 2014 |accessdate=7 February 2014}} *{{cite web |url= https://www.theatlantic.com/health/archive/2014/03/doctors-1-source-for-healthcare-information-wikipedia/284206/ |title=Doctors’ #1 Source for Healthcare Information: Wikipedia |first=Julie |last=Beck |work=[[The Atlantic|theatlantic.com]] |date=5 March 2014 |accessdate=5 March 2014}} </ref>
===Other wikis=== {{main article|List of medical wikis}}
==Regulation== In the United States the [[Food and Drug Administration]] offers guidance for health industry organizations which share information online.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://blogs.fda.gov/fdavoice/index.php/2014/06/fda-issues-draft-guidances-for-industry-on-social-media-and-internet-communications-about-medical-products-designed-with-patients-in-mind/ |title=FDA Issues Draft Guidances for Industry on Social Media and Internet Communications About Medical Products: Designed with Patients in Mind |author=FDA Voice |work=blogs.fda.gov |date=17 June 2014 |accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.fda.gov/AboutFDA/CentersOffices/OfficeofMedicalProductsandTobacco/CDER/ucm397791.htm |title=About the Center for Drug Evaluation and Research > For Industry: Using Social Media |author=Food and Drug Administration |work=fda.gov |date=2014-07-07 |accessdate=5 September 2014}}</ref>

{{More footnotes|date=December 2008}} The '''Healthy Life Years''' indicator (HLY) is a European structural indicator computed by [https://web.archive.org/web/20120301003227/http://epp.eurostat.ec.europa.eu/portal/page/portal/product_details/dataset?p_product_code=HLTH_HLYE Eurostat]. It is one of the summary measures of population health, known as health expectancies,<ref>[http://www.eurohex.eu/pdf/Glossary_v4.pdf Glossary EurOhex website]</ref> composite measures of health that combine [[Mortality rate|mortality]] and [[morbidity]] data to represent overall population health on a single indicator.<ref>J.-M. Robine. ''Summarizing health status''. In: Pencheon D, Guest C, Melzer D, Gray JAM, editors. Oxford Handbook of Public Health Practice. 2nd ed. Oxford: Oxford University Press; 2006. p. 160-168</ref> HLY measures the number of remaining years that a person of a certain age is expected to live without disability. It is actually a disability-free [[life expectancy]].
== History == The European Union has decided to include a small set of health expectancies among its European Community Health Indicators (ECHI) to provide synthetic measures of disability, chronic morbidity, and perceived health. Therefore the Minimum European Health Module (MEHM), composed of 3 general questions covering these dimensions,<ref>B. Cox, H. Van Oyen, E. Cambois, C. Jagger, S. Le Roy, J-M Robine, I.Romieu. The reliability of the Minimum European Health Module. ''International Journal of Public Health'' 2009;(54):55-60 (DOI 10.1007/s00038-009-7104-y), p57</ref> has been introduced into the Eurostat EU-Statistics on Income and Living Conditions Survey (EU-SILC)<ref>[http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=CELEX:32003R1177:EN:NOT Regulation (EC) No 1177/2003 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 16 June 2003 concerning Community statistics on income and living conditions (EU-SILC)]</ref> to improve the comparability of health expectancies between countries. In addition life expectancy without long term activity limitation, based on the disability question, was selected in 2004 to be one of the structural indicators to be examined every year, during the European Spring Council for assessing the EU strategic goals ([[Lisbon Strategy]]) under the name of “Healthy Life Years” (HLY)'''.<ref>[http://ec.europa.eu/health/ph_information/indicators/lifeyears_en.htm Health Life Years in the core of the Lisbon Strategy ]</ref> '''Furthermore the European Union is co-funding a Joint Action on Chronic Diseases and Promoting Healthy Ageing across the Life Cycle (CHRODIS-JA).<ref>http://www.chrodis.eu/</ref> This aims to promote and facilitate a process of exchange and transfer of good practices between European countries and regions, addressing chronic conditions, with a specific focus on health promotion and prevention of chronic conditions, multi-morbidity and diabetes.'''
Detailed information on the Health Expectancies in Europe are available from the EurOhex Advanced research on European health expectancies<ref>[http://www.eurohex.eu EurOhex]</ref> while latest Healthy Life Years values can be found on the general public website devoted to the Healthy Life Years.<ref>[http://www.healthy-life-years.eu healthy-life-years.eu]</ref>
== Context == Dramatic increases in [[life expectancy]] in the most developed countries - and therefore in the countries of the European Union - constitute one of the most remarkable advances of the last decades. But why prolong life if this is to be accompanied by increases in severe mental and physical impairment? Thus a further challenge confronts the European Community: :''increasing life expectancy in good health.''
In this context, the classical mortality indicators are no longer sufficient to monitor the health status of European populations. The availability of health expectancy indicators dividing life expectancy into life spent in different states of health is useful to health authorities in the field of [[public health]] and [[health policy|health policies]] provided that these indicators allow comparisons over time and between geographic areas and between socio-economic groups in society. As the post-war generation reaches retirement, the pace of ageing will increase dramatically in our European societies, with profound social effects. HLY is an important indicator : * Health of a population is inherently difficult to measure because it is often defined differently among individuals, populations, cultures, and even across time periods. * Many studies focus on measures such as physical impairment or disability in functional tasks or presence of a specific chronic disease. Self-assessed health, being much more global and subjective in nature, can incorporate a variety of aspects of health including cognitive and emotional as well as physical status, and therefore provide insights into the needs of an [[ageing]] society. Hence, self-assessed health measures as HLY may be a particularly important indicator of the potential demand for health services and long-term care needs. * The two components of the calculation of the HLY are life tables and self-perceived disability assessed by health surveys. From 1995 to 2001, data from the Eurostat European Community Household Panel (ECHP) survey have been used for the EU-15 Member States. Its successor, the Eurostat EU-SILC has been used from 2005 onwards for the EU-25 and then 27 Member States.{{cn|date=April 2015}}
== Example == [[File:HLY 2010.jpg|thumb|Healthy Life Years in Europe - 2010]] * The HLY estimates are provided for the 27 EU Member States using the EU-SILC data for 2010 (see graph above) * The first analyses of the healthy life years values disclose significant inequalities among the European countries.<ref>C. Jagger, C. Gillies, F. Mascone, E. Cambois, H. Van Oyen, W.J. Nusselder, J.-M. Robine, EHLEIS team. Inequalities in healthy life years in the 25 countries of the European Union in 2005: a cross-national meta-regression analysis. ''The Lancet'' 2008;372(9656):2124-2131 (DOI 10.1016/S0140-6736(08)61594-9)</ref>
==Statistical Findings== Different estimations are made for men and women. In 2015, the number of healthy years of women in the EU-28 was estimated to be at 63.3 years and of men to be at 62.6 years. The interesting part of this is that the gender gap was considerably smaller in regards to healthy life years than to overall life expectancy. This would imply that biologically, gender would not really affect the rate and time at which humans would become healthy yet gender would play a role in how long human beings would be able to live in an unhealthy state.
==Data Sources and their Availability== Eurostat calculates information about the healthy life years at three different ages during a person's life. One is at birth, another is at age 50, and the third is at age 65, with an indicator used separately for men and women. The data is calculated and collected by using mortality statistics as well as self perceived longstanding activity limitations- a dimension that captures longstanding limitation in regards to health and/or disability to perform usual and frequent activities. An example of a question that might be asked concerning the longstanding activity limitation is: "For the last six months, to what extent have you been limited because of a health problem in activities that people usually do?" Some available answers are "severely limited", "limited but not severely", or "not limited at all".
==See also== * [[Disability-adjusted life year]] * [[Quality-adjusted life year]]
== References == {{reflist|colwidth=30em}} * J.-M. Robine, C. Jagger, Euro-REVES group. Creating a coherent set of indicators to monitor health across Europe: the Euro-REVES 2 project. ''European Journal of Public Health'' 2003;13(3):6-14.
== External links == * [http://www.healthy-life-years.eu/ Healthy Life Years] * [http://www.eurohex.eu EurOhex] * [http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/statistics-explained/index.php/Healthy_life_years_statistics Healthy life years statistics] * [http://ec.europa.eu/health/index_en.htm Europa - Public Health] * [http://ec.europa.eu/health/heidi/ Heidi Wiki] * [http://reves.site.ined.fr/en/ REVES, the International Network on Health Expectancy and the Disability Process] * [http://www.healthypeople.gov/ US Healthy People] * [http://www.who.int/en/ WHO | World Health Organization] * [http://ec.europa.eu/health-eu/ Health-EU Portal] the official public health portal of the European Union * [http://www.health-success.co.uk UK Health Success] [[Category:Ageing]] [[Category:Global health]]

revision.comment: Robot - Speedily moving category Seventh-day Adventist leaders to [[:Category:Seventh-day Adventist religious workers]] per [[WP:CFDS|CFDS]].
revision.text:
{{about||the English footballer|John Burden (footballer)|the Belizean politician|John Burdon}} {{Infobox person | name = John Allen Burden | image = John Burden.gif | image_size = | caption = | birth_date = | birth_place = 1862 | death_date = 1942 | death_place = [[Redlands, California]] | occupation = Pastor, Missionary, Administrator | spouse = }} {{Seventh-day Adventism}} '''John Allen Burden''' (1862–1942) was a [[Seventh-day Adventist Church|Seventh-day Adventist]] [[Minister of religion|minister]], [[Administration (business)|administrator]], and [[medical missionary]] instrumental in founding [[Sanatorium|sanitariums]], restaurants, and health food factories. At the age of 9, John attended Adventist meetings for the first time and was introduced to the writings of [[Ellen G. White]], which left a lifelong impression upon him. Five years later he was baptized, and at the age of 18 (1880) moved with his family to [[Oregon]]. John met [[Eleanor A. Baxter]] (1865–1933) as a student at Healdsburg College (now [[Pacific Union College]]). They were married in 1888 while working for the Rural Health Retreat (later [[St. Helena Sanitarium]]), of which John became manager in 1891. In 1901 the Burdens went to [[Australia]] where they helped [[Merritt G. Kellogg]] who was founding the Wahroonga Sanitarium (now the [[Sydney Adventist Hospital]]) in [[Wahroonga, New South Wales|Wahroonga]], [[Sydney]]. By March 1904 the Burdens returned to the United States. [[Ellen G. White]] encouraged them not to unite with [[John Harvey Kellogg]] in [[Battle Creek, Michigan|Battle Creek]], [[Michigan]]. Instead, John sought to establish a sanitarium near [[Los Angeles, California|Los Angeles]]. Eight miles from the city he discovered the Glendale Hotel that had cost $60,000 to build in 1886. However, because of local business failures, property value had declined so that he was able to purchase it for $12,500. When it opened in 1905, Burden was the manager of the sanitarium, and Eleanor the bookkeeper. The sanitarium prospered under Burden's careful management. In 1904 [[Ellen G. White]] urged for the establishment of another sanitarium in [[southern California]]. A resort hotel at [[Loma Linda, California|Loma Linda]] was found that was available for $110,000, a price too high. On May 4, 1905 she met with the Burdens and others at the railroad station in Los Angeles on her way to the [[General Conference Session]] in [[Washington, D.C.]] Burden told her of the property, and she expressed definite interest in it, asking him to write her about it after his next visit to the property. When Burden's letterJohn Burden to Ellen G. White, May 7, 1905, [[Ellen G. White Estate]] arrived in Washington, she urged him by telegram to
secure the property by all means. . . . This is the very property we ought to have. Do not delay; for it is just what is needed.Ellen G. White, Letter 139, 1905
Borrowing the down payment, Burden succeeded in purchasing the property for $40,000 and was put in charge of the new sanitarium.Ellen G. White, Letter 169, 1905 The final price, with discounts for early payment, came to $38,900. After Ellen White found out that the property was secured she wrote in her diary:
I am surprised more and more that the Lord has in His abundant mercy wrought in our behalf.Ellen G. White, Manuscript 176, 1905, Aug. 25, 1905
Founded as the College of Medical Evangelists, the institution exists today as [[Loma Linda University]]. A building on campus, Burden Hall, remains named for John Burden. At one time, it was home to the [[Loma Linda University Church]] of [[Seventh-day Adventists]] until the congregation outgrew it. Burden Hall now houses the Office of University Relations, is used for classes during the week, and is home to a Sabbath School class each Saturday. Burden continued to manage the facilities at Loma Linda until 1915 when he became manager, and Eleanor the matron, of [[Paradise Valley Sanitarium]] (1916–1924; 1925–1934). After Eleanor's death in 1933, John retired, but in 1939 he returned to Loma Linda to serve as chaplain, counseling young medical missionaries and the staff of the College of Medical Evangelists. Burden died as the result of a car accident on his return from a Bible study in [[Redlands, California|Redlands]], California. Burden's personal collection of some 650 pages of Ellen White's letters (half of them addressed to him) was published as ''Loma Linda Messages'' (Loma Linda, CA: College of Medical Evangelists, 1934). == See also == {{Portal|Seventh-day Adventist Church|Christianity|Biography}} * [[Loma Linda University]] * [[History of the Seventh-day Adventist Church]] == References == {{reflist|2}} {{authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Burden, John}} [[Category:Pacific Union College alumni]] [[Category:1862 births]] [[Category:1942 deaths]] [[Category:Seventh-day Adventists in health science]] [[Category:Road incident deaths in California]] [[Category:American Seventh-day Adventists]] [[Category:Seventh-day Adventist religious workers]] [[Category:American Seventh-day Adventist ministers]] [[Category:Seventh-day Adventist administrators]] [[Category:American Seventh-day Adventist missionaries]] [[Category:History of the Seventh-day Adventist Church]] [[Category:Christian medical missionaries]] [[Category:Seventh-day Adventist missionaries in Australia]] [[Category:American expatriates in Australia]]
